Ïù¥ÏäπÌôò: ÏûêÍ∏∞ÏÜåÍ∞ú Î∂ÄÌÉÅÎìúÎ¶ΩÎãàÎã§.
Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎØº: ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµ ÎåÄÌëú Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎØºÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ‚Äò6Î∂Ñ ÎßåÏóê ÎßåÎìúÎäî Î©ãÏßÑ ÏáºÌïëÎ™∞‚ÄôÏù¥ÎûÄ ÎúªÏúºÎ°ú ÏûêÏÇ¨Î™∞ÏùÑ ÎàÑÍµ¨ÎÇò ÎöùÎî± ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ÏûÖÎãàÎã§.

Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎØº: Ï≤òÏùåÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏãúÏû•ÏùÑ Îã§ Î®πÏûê, Í∑∏Îü∞ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏùÄ ÏóÜÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïã†Í∑ú ÏÖÄÎü¨ ÏûÖÏû•ÏóêÏÑú Îèà Ïïà Îì§Ïù¥Í≥† ÏâΩÍ≤å ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÌîåÎû´ÌèºÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Í≥†Ïûê ÌñàÏñ¥Ïöî. Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å Ïã†Í∑ú Ïú†Ï†ÄÎßå Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌûà ÎäòÎ†§ÎèÑ Ïñ∏Ï††Í∞ÄÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ï¶àÍ∞Ä ÎÇòÏò¨ Í±∞Îùº ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌñàÏñ¥Ïöî.
Ïù¥ÏäπÌôò: Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ï¶àÎäî Ï¢Ä ÎÇòÏôîÎÇòÏöî?
Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎØº: Ïù¥ÎØ∏ ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµ ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò ÏûêÏ≤¥ÎßåÏúºÎ°ú BEPÎ•º ÎÑòÏùÄ ÏßÄÎäî Ï¢Ä ÎêêÍ≥†Ïöî. Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌûà Ïö∞ÏÉÅÌñ• Ï§ëÏù¥ÏóêÏöî. Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎØº: Í∏∞Ï°¥ ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµÏùÄ ÏΩîÎî© ÏóÜÏù¥ ÏóêÎîîÌÑ∞Î°ú ÏâΩÍ≤å ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ïû•Ï†êÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÏßÄÎßå, Ìõ®Ïî¨ ÎÜíÏùÄ ÏûêÏú†ÎèÑÎ•º ÏõêÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÎ∂ÑÎì§Ïùò ÏöîÍµ¨Î•º Î™®Îëê Ï∂©Ï°±ÏãúÌÇ§Í∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†§Ïõ†ÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµ ÌîÑÎ°úÎ•º Ï§ÄÎπÑÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ïù¥ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï¥Í≤∞Ìï† Í≤ÉÏù∏ÏßÄÏóê Ï§ëÏ†êÏùÑ ÎëêÏóàÍ≥† Í∑∏ Í≤∞Í≥º ‚ÄòÎ∏îÎ°ù Î©îÏù¥Ïª§‚ÄôÎùºÎäî Í∏∞Îä•Ïù¥ ÌÉÑÏÉùÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµ ÌîÑÎ°úÏùò ‚ÄòÎ∏îÎ°ù Î©îÏù¥Ïª§‚ÄôÎ•º ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎ©¥ Ï†úÏûëÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ Í∏∞Ï°¥ ÏóêÎîîÌÑ∞ÏóêÏÑú Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÏöîÏÜåÎ•º ÏΩîÎìúÎ°ú ÏûêÏú†Î°≠Í≤å ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑ Îøê ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, ÏóêÎîîÌÑ∞ ÎÇ¥ÏóêÏÑú ÏöîÏÜåÎ•º Ìé∏ÏßëÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ìå®ÎÑêÍπåÏßÄÎèÑ ÏâΩÍ≤å ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÎÇº Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∏∞Ï°¥ Ïõπ ÎπåÎçîÏóêÏÑú Í≤ΩÌóòÌï† Ïàò ÏóÜÏóàÎçò ÎÜíÏùÄ ÏûêÏú†ÎèÑÎ°ú ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º Ï†úÏûëÌïòÏãúÎ©¥ÏÑú, ÎèôÏãúÏóê Ïõπ ÎπåÎçîÏùò Ïû•Ï†êÏù∏ ÏàòÏ†ï Î∞è Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Ïùò Ìé∏Î¶¨Ìï®ÍπåÏßÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÏã§ Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑ Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§.

Ïù¥ÏäπÌôò: ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º ÌôúÏö©Ìïú ÏûêÏú†Î°úÏö¥ Ìé∏Ïßë Ï¢ãÏùÄÎç∞ Ïù¥Í±¥ ÏùºÎ∞òÏù∏ÌïúÌÖåÎäî Ïñ¥Î†µÏßÄ ÏïäÎÇòÏöî?

Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎØº: ÌòÑÏû¨ ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµ ÌîÑÎ°úÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º Ï†úÏûëÌïú Í≥†Í∞ùÎãòÏùò Ïõî ÏöîÍ∏àÏ†ú ÎπÑÏö©ÏùÑ ÌååÌä∏ÎÑàÎ∂ÑÎì§Í≥º ÏâêÏñ¥ÌïòÎäî ÌòïÌÉúÏùò Ï†úÌú¥ Í≥ÑÏïΩÏùÑ Îß∫ÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÎòêÌïú, ÏãùÏä§ÏÉµ ÌååÌä∏ÎÑà ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ ÌôçÎ≥¥ Ìö®Í≥ºÎ•º Í∏∞ÎåÄÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑ Í±∞ÏòàÏöî.

posts.title: ILA Evo: Meta‚Äôs journey to reimagine fiber optic in-line amplifier sites
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Today‚Äôs rapidly evolving landscape of use cases that demand highly performant and efficient network infrastructure is placing new emphasis on how in-line amplifiers (ILAs) are designed and deployed.
Meta‚Äôs ILA Evo effort seeks to reimagine how an ILA site could be deployed to improve speed and cost while making a step function improvement in power efficiency.
Over the past year, Meta has been on a journey to reimagine fiber optic in-line amplifier (ILA) sites. An important piece of network infrastructure, ILAs¬† serve to amplify optical signals and are often placed in remote locations between data centers. If one ILA fails, an entire intercity route fails, and if one ILA cannot grow, the entire fiber route is constrained. Meta is excited to introduce new ideas and concepts to help modernize the ILAs for tomorrow.
To that end, we‚Äôve launched the ILA Evo effort to overcome the historic design constraints of today‚Äôs ILAs, namely:
The minimal skilled labor and raw material required at the deployment site;
The requirement that buildings meet local snow, wind, and seismic load along with fire codes and health and safety regulation ‚Äì¬† plus lifespan greater than 25 years;¬†
This new effort seeks to propel advancement through several new requirements:¬†
Requiring the building and inside plant (ISP) must be deployed in three to four days.
Reducing the need for specialized heavy equipment (avoiding the cost and time for heavy-lift cranes to travel to a remote site).
Minimizing concrete (avoid cost and time to transport, form, tie rebar, pour, and cure concrete).
Reducing the power usage effectiveness (PUE) to less than 1.5 ‚Äì nowhere near Meta‚Äôs operational data center PUE average of 1.09 (2023 average), but an achievable and significant improvement.
A short history of ILAs
Fiber optic cable networks have seen exponential growth in both size and capacity since GTE launched the first fiber optic network in 1977. U.S. network operators would install 20,039 mi (32,250 km) of intercity fiber routes by 1985. This would quadruple to 83,618 mi (134,570 km) by 1989 and double again to 159,779 mi (257,149 km) by 1998, with MCI, Sprint, USTelecom, and WilTel being the major players in those early days.
As fiber was rolled out along roads, railways, and pipelines, real estate to house optical signal repeaters was developed in parallel. What later became known ILA sites were spaced 18 to 25 miles (30 to 40 km) apart. With rapid improvements in both optical fiber purity and composition, plus advancements in optronics, spacing soon doubled into the 50 to 60 mile (80 to 100 km) range where it has largely remained until today.
Early ILA building designs were roughly modeled on Bell Telephone central offices, albeit a shrunken down version: concrete shells (or stick framed construction on a steel I-beam base) placed atop concrete foundations; wall-mounted HVAC units; -48V power distribution; lead-acid batteries; diesel backup generators and so forth surrounded by chain link fences.¬†
Buildings were constructed in a central location with ISP fitted into the shell before shipment to the site (via specialized motor carrier) and placed with a heavy-load crane. However, unlike the remarkable (and ongoing) advancements in fiber and optronics (e.g., CWDM to DWDM to Coherent DWDM), ILA sites themselves have received little attention.
Current ILA site design.
Today‚Äôs ILA buildings are often larger, with more efficient HVAC systems. Components like security and building access systems have been modernized, but if you dropped a field technician from 1990 into one of today‚Äôs ILAs, they‚Äôd have little difficulty navigating. Historically, ILA sites haven‚Äôt required significant evolution, however newfound capacity growth and innovation has warranted the development of new ILA approaches.
The structure of ILA Evo
Working with global engineering consultancy AECOM, we‚Äôve organized the problem and our engineering efforts into several categories: different building systems and foundations; a new ISP installation method; alternative ballistics protection; introducing more efficient cooling; and modernizing backup power systems.
Building system
Identify lightweight building designs which can be flat packed for easy, quick shipment and unloaded at the deployment site using a lift gate. Our emphasis has been on buildings composed of fiberglass-reinforced polymer (FRP) aka glass-reinforced polymer (GRP) wall and roof panels light enough for two people to handle, but sturdy enough to meet our design needs. There is a robust ecosystem of companies offering solutions in this space. This approach also allows for slightly taller buildings than prefab to provide additional overhead space for HVAC system elements or other components.¬†
Lightweight flat-pack buildings suitable for a wide range of local and climatic conditions.
Building foundations
Where geology permits, utilize low- or no-concrete foundation designs for easier deployment into both greenfield and brownfield sites. Typically, ILA buildings sit atop slab-on-grade foundations with a perimeter edge return. This design works well in a variety of soil conditions and is well suited to the weights involved. However, as we pursue lighter buildings, other foundation designs become possible. In particular, the project has focused on steel or FRP I-beams over concrete pad footings or helical steel screw piles. Both options offer the potential for both lower cost and more rapid deployment.
Lighter buildings can unlock alternative foundation designs like helical steel screw piles.
Manufactured owner-furnished equipment ISP
Devise a process for rapidly installing ISP to minimize post-construction interior dust and debris clean-up. We envision employing a manufactured owner-furnished equipment (MOFE) process for ISP: six rack modules consisting of equipment racks and overhead tiers supported by an exoskeleton, and movable on casters, are preassembled in a centralized, clean factory-like environment. Like the building system, these can be delivered on regular trucks with lift gates and modules rolled into the building to be bolted down.
MOFE ISP for rapid on-site installation.
Ballistics
Where required, provide appropriate ballistics protection; e.g., NIJ 0101.06 Level IIA. However, we felt assigning this function to the building system wasn‚Äôt the only option, so we‚Äôve left open the possibility of ballistic privacy fences and other ideas as ways to solve this requirement which offers more flexibility for what ‚Äúinside the fence‚Äù could look like.
Cooling
The single biggest opportunity to improve PUE lies in introducing more efficient cooling tech combined with higher temperature set points. PUE hasn‚Äôt historically been a focus metric for small telecoms sites, but this needs to change. Traditional sites use self-contained, wall-mounted HVAC units that rely on large fans to force air through the building without a duct system. This approach works, but is not very efficient: North American ILA PUE is typically between 2.5 and 3.0. However, over the past few years, power requirements have moved from 600-800W per rack into the 2-4 kW range. With increasing power density, we began looking for other options which could do the job more effectively and efficiently (i.e., reduce PUE).
Main elements:
Radically improve ILA site HVAC efficiency with advanced passive (i.e., compressorless) and/or liquid-based cooling tech.
Because ILAs are unmanned, allow the building to run hotter: e.g., increase temperature set points from typical 22¬∞C (72¬∞F) to >35¬∞C (95¬∞F); most optical transport kit is GR-63-CORE NEBS-3 compliant and able to run continuously at 40¬∞C (104¬∞F).
Thermally ‚Äúleaky‚Äù building systems; i.e., not air leaks , but lower R-value walls.
Move rectifiers and batteries into outdoor cabinets: more space for optical gear and less heat generation.
Utilize cool surface materials and coatings (e.g., heat reflective paints) to further reduce solar heat load.
The project investigated many hyper efficient options such as chilled beams (ceiling mounted, air-to-liquid heat exchangers) combined with a ground-based heat exchange (water or glycol circulating in a closed, buried ground loop), but unfortunately, none could handle 24 x 2 kW. However, a loop thermosyphon system coupled with a high-efficiency compressor (a helper used during the hottest part of the hottest days) could achieve our PUE <1.5 goal. Similarly, scaled-down chiller and computer room air conditioning (CRAC) units supplying liquid cooling into a thoughtfully designed floor plan could get us to that same goal.
The project hasn‚Äôt made a final selection yet as these technologies will make our goal of ‚Äúno cranes‚Äù difficult to achieve, but we believe we have line-of-sight to a solution.
Backup Power
Investigate modern alternatives to diesel generators and lead-acid batteries for standby power. We are considering substitutions for diesel generator backup that may include H2 fuel cells, capacitors, or other solutions based on location and commercial feasibility.
Additionally, we have investigated a range of battery technologies. At the moment, the economics aren‚Äôt attractive for this scale. In the meantime, we believe an H2 fuel cell combined with a small NaNiCl molten salt battery system (to handle site load for a few minutes while the fuel cell spins up and takes load) is an attractive, low maintenance solution.
ILA Evo site design.
Macro benefits of ILA Evo
Beyond the technical aspects, ILA Evo brings potentially powerful commercial and risk management benefits: supply chain and ability to stockpile.¬†
Starting with the familiar current ILA supply chain, the chief advantage is completing the majority of work at a single site. However, this creates challenges in terms of cost, the complexity of scaling production up or down, and the difficulty and cost of transporting the necessary heavy equipment to remote sites. Additionally, the feasibility of stockpiling current ILA buildings is debatable: The space requirement would consume valuable real estate at the production site and staging them off-site simply amplifies the transportation issue to move them multiple times.
Typical supply chain for today‚Äôs ILAs.
Looking to ILA Evo and starting with a new disaggregated supply chain, many ISP materials and other items like HVAC units would most likely come from the usual sources, but these sources already tend to be scaled. Other elements such as the building system and MOFE ISP would be manufactured or assembled by companies that are not necessarily part of today‚Äôs telecom ecosystem.
Additionally, the process is very different. Concrete and stick framed buildings are created via a construction process, the nature of which is bespoke and relatively low volume. ILA Evo is predominantly manufacturing or assembly processes, which are inherently geared toward scale, including the possibility of 24√ó7 operations.
Supply Chain envisioned for ILA Evo.
Next, stockpiling. It‚Äôs not hard to imagine manufacturing 500 building systems, packed efficiently and ready for next day shipment. One can also imagine 2,000 MOFE ISP modules (four for each 24 rack building) preassembled and ready to ship. Additionally, purchasing in bulk allows vendors to de-risk their own investments and achieve scales required for cost compression not possible with today‚Äôs designs.
Crossover with current ILA design
One final consideration is identifying ideas that could be retrofitted into existing sites. Putting aside a different building system and MOFE ISP, the HVAC system and the other ‚Äúefficiency tweaks‚Äù could go into existing sites. Similarly, H2 fuel cell backup power could be applied. We also expect to explore substituting commodity ISP materials for their FRP analogs. If this works, FRP equipment racks and ladder racks (which have a lower carbon footprint than steel or aluminum) could also be an option for existing sites.
What‚Äôs next?
Following the completion of our research and design phase, there are a number of next steps planned for 2025:
The project has already engaged fiber optic operators in North America and Europe to gather early feedback and gain their insights. In the coming months, we expect to expand this consultation with operators in Latin America, Africa, Middle East, and Asia.
A prototype site showcasing some of the best ideas from this work.
We plan to create and broadly share blueprints, bills of material, and analyses that show our path and help seed operators‚Äô own research, engineering, and technical real estate product development.
The post ILA Evo: Meta‚Äôs journey to reimagine fiber optic in-line amplifier sites appeared first on Engineering at Meta.

posts.title: IntelliJ IDEA 2025.1 EAP Is Open!¬†
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
We‚Äôre kicking off the new year with the first Early Access Program (EAP) build for IntelliJ IDEA 2025.1! This is your chance to get an exclusive first look at the upcoming features and improvements designed to make your coding workflow more efficient than ever.
You can download this version from our website, update directly from within the IDE, use our free Toolbox App, or install it via snap packages for Ubuntu.




New to the EAP? Our introductory blog post explains how the program works, why your feedback is important to us, and how you can get involved.
Stay tuned for EAP updates over the next few weeks to try out new features in IntelliJ IDEA. Test them out, provide your feedback, and play a big part in shaping the future of the IDE.
Java¬†
Early Java 24 support
We already offer partial support for the upcoming Java 24! Be among the first to explore its latest features in IntelliJ IDEA and stay ahead of the curve. Simply set your SDK to Oracle OpenJDK 24 and adjust the Language Level accordingly in Project Structure | Project Settings | Project.




Frameworks and technologies
Faster creation of Spring beans
Starting with this EAP, you can create Spring beans directly from the New‚Ä¶ or Generate‚Ä¶ menus. There is no need to create an empty class and annotate it manually ‚Äì just select the option, and you‚Äôre ready to go!




Check out this improvement to streamline your Spring workflow and save time!
Build tools
Support for Gradle Daemon toolchains
Starting with Gradle 8.13, you can define the exact JVM for the Gradle Daemon using the native Gradle toolchain. Previously, this was only possible for the project itself. With this change, the IDE syncs with Gradle‚Äôs configuration and even lets Gradle download the required JVM automatically when needed.
Our settings chooser in Preferences/Settings | Build Tools | Gradle remains fully synced with Gradle‚Äôs config. While this setup is optional, we encourage you to use it to prevent Daemon JVM errors and ensure projects sync smoothly every time.




Debugger¬†
Easier toolbar customization in the Debugger tool window
With so many powerful features in our debugger, you can now tailor the toolbar to fit your workflow!
Right-click next to the kebab menu in the top pane and select Add to Debugger Toolbar. You‚Äôll then see a list of all available actions ‚Äì pick the ones that suit your project and make debugging even smoother.




Text popups in inline hints
When debugging and inspecting a value that contains marked-up text, you can now view it with proper formatting instead of as a plain, lengthy string. For example, if the value is an XML input for a parser, it will be displayed in a structured, readable format.
Previously, this feature was only available for watches. Now, we‚Äôve extended the same functionality to inline debugging, ensuring consistency across both views.




That‚Äôs it for the first week of the IntelliJ IDEA 2025.1 EAP! Check out the release notes for the full list of changes.
Stay tuned for weekly updates as we unveil more features. Share your thoughts in the comments to this blog post or on X, and report any bugs via our issue tracker. Let‚Äôs shape the future of IntelliJ IDEA together!
Happy developing!

posts.creator: Oleg Zinovyev
posts.title: The CLion 2025.1 Early Access Program Is Open
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The Early Access Program (EAP) for CLion 2025.1 has officially launched. The first EAP build, 251.14649.40, is here to provide an early look at some of the improvements coming in the next major release. You can download the build for free from the link below, via the Toolbox App, or as a snap package if you‚Äôre using Ubuntu.
DOWNLOAD CLION 2025.1 EAP
For the first EAP release, we‚Äôve focused on improvements for CLion Nova and embedded development. Keep reading to get all the key details!
CLion Nova
Thanks to ongoing feature additions and performance enhancements, our new language engine, CLion Nova, is increasingly ready to serve as the default engine for all users. With the start of the 2025.1 EAP, CLion Nova includes a new batch of the most requested features from CLion Classic, including several smart keys and actions.
Smart keys
Smart keys are actions designed to help you write code faster and enhance your overall experience in the IDE. One such feature we‚Äôve added in the first 2025.1 EAP allows the IDE to ignore indentation when you press ‚å´ (macOS) or Backspace (Windows or Linux). To try it, go to Settings | Editor | General | Smart Keys, scroll down to Unindent on Backspace, and select Disabled from the drop-down menu.

                        


Another update relates to the Surround selection on typing quote or brace smart key, which allows you to surround selected text with quotation marks or braces such as [], {}, and (). We‚Äôve now added support for < > and the ability to disable the feature entirely. When the feature is enabled, simply select the required text and surround it by pressing the desired punctuation mark.

                        


Moving the caret to the start or end of a code block
CLion Nova now supports moving the caret to the beginning or end of a code block using the following shortcuts:
Move to Code Block End ‚Äì ‚åò‚å•] (macOS) or Ctrl+] (Windows or Linux)
Move to Code Block Start ‚Äì ‚åò‚å• [ (macOS) or Ctrl+[ (Windows or Linux)
Move to Code Block End with Selection ‚Äì ‚åò‚å•‚áß] (macOS) or Ctrl+Shift+] (Windows or Linux)
Move to Code Block Start with Selection ‚Äì ‚åò‚å•‚áß[ (macOS) or Ctrl+Shift+[ (Windows or Linux)
Support for GoogleTest and Catch2 in Bazel projects
CLion Nova now supports the GoogleTest and Catch2 testing frameworks when working with Bazel projects.
Embedded development
The embedded development updates in this first EAP build mainly include new functionality for the Serial Port Monitor plugin and UX improvements to the Debug Servers configuration option.
Serial Port Monitor
We‚Äôve extended the functionality of the Serial Port Monitor plugin to make it more useful for embedded developers working with devices that use a serial port such as Arduino and ESP32.
We‚Äôve added the ability to view and manage the DTR, DSR, RTS, and CTS hardware control signals, giving you more control over your attached devices. For example, the DTR signal is connected to the hardware reset on Arduino and many ESP32-based boards.
To enable hardware control signals:
In the Serial Connections tool window, navigate to the Connect tab.
Select the desired COM port.¬†
Click the Show HW controls checkbox.




The control options and indicators will then appear in the COM port tab.




We‚Äôve also added the ability to view timestamps in the monitor output ‚Äì see [11:27:44.489] in the screenshot above. This option is useful if you want to track the sequence of messages in detail when debugging or troubleshooting. You can turn it on in the left-hand panel of the Serial Connections tool window.




Debug servers
In v2024.3, we introduced the new Debug Servers configuration option that allows you to set up a dedicated debug server for a particular debug probe. This feature simplifies the process of running or debugging build targets.¬†
For the upcoming 2025.1 release, we‚Äôre working on UX improvements to the Debug Server settings based on user feedback and bug fixes. Some of these updates are already available in this EAP build.
To learn about the other features we plan to introduce in v2025.1, read the blog post about our roadmap.
DOWNLOAD CLION 2025.1 EAP
Call for feedback
We value your feedback, as your experiences and insights are essential to our mission of continuously improving CLion. This is especially valuable during the Early Access Program, as it helps us refine and prepare new features for the stable release. Please share your ideas and feedback in the comments below or submit them to our issue tracker.
We would also be interested in setting up a quick call with you to learn more about your specific use cases. Let us know if you would like to participate!

posts.creator: Rachel Appel
posts.title: dotInsights | January 2025
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Did you know? The Y2K bug, or ‚ÄúMillennium Bug,‚Äù was a programming issue caused by storing years with only two digits (e.g., ‚Äú1999‚Äù as ‚Äú99‚Äù) to save memory. As 2000 approached, systems risked interpreting ‚Äú00‚Äù as 1900, leading to potential errors in calculations and data processing.
Fears of disruptions in critical systems like banking and utilities prompted a global effort to update software. In the end, the fixes worked, and major issues were avoided.
If you started your dev career later, have you wondered what it was like to be a programmer in the 90‚Äôs?




Welcome to dotInsights by JetBrains! This newsletter is the home for recent .NET and software development related information.




üåü Featured Content
The .NET advocates have been wondering if AI can accurately predict computing trends, since AI is still a hot technology. So this month, we bring you featured content from JetBrains AI!
Here‚Äôs what we asked: ‚ÄúHow do you see .NET and C# evolving in 2025? Tell me some predictions. Keep it between 400-500 words and cite your reasons why.‚Äù
? Predicting the evolution of .NET and C# by 2025 involves examining current trends, Microsoft‚Äôs strategy, and the broader software development landscape. Here‚Äôs what we might expect:
1. Continued Expansion of .NET 7/8 Unified Platform
By 2025, the unified nature of the .NET platform introduced starting from .NET 5 should become more robust and expansive. Microsoft has been consolidating frameworks like .NET Core, Xamarin, and the traditional .NET Framework into a singular platform. This means developers will have more seamless experiences across web, mobile, desktop, and cloud apps. Expect more refined cross-platform development tools, greater performance optimization, and deeper integration with languages like C#.
Reason: The push for cross-platform compatibility remains strong, given the heterogeneous environment of devices and operating systems. The success of frameworks like Flutter and innovations in Rust could nudge Microsoft to double down on a unified framework that remains competitive.
2. Significant Enhancements to C# and AI-Driven Development
C# is already recognized for its features that embrace developer productivity, like nullability annotations, pattern matching, and asynchronous programming. By 2025, we can expect C# to integrate more systems programming features without compromising ease of use. Additionally, AI-driven tools powered by GitHub Copilot or Azure AI will likely influence the language itself, incorporating features tailored for predictive code generation and error-proofing.
Reason: The growth of AI tools is fundamentally altering how developers write code. Microsoft‚Äôs investment in OpenAI, GitHub Copilot, and Visual Studio tooling suggests advanced AI models will integrate tightly, making C# a ‚Äúsmart-first‚Äù language for enterprise applications.
3. Focus on Cloud-Native and Microservices with .NET
Cloud computing is dominating software infrastructure, and .NET has been enhancing its support for cloud-native development alongside technologies like Docker and Kubernetes. By 2025, we should see streamlined microservice development features and tools baked into .NET for increased scalability, including native support for multi-cloud architectures.
Reason: Enterprises continue to adopt the cloud en masse, and platforms must adapt to support distributed systems and containerization. Microsoft‚Äôs Azure ecosystem will likely drive these .NET innovations.
4. More Emphasis on Blazor and WebAssembly
Blazor, which allows developers to write full-stack web apps using C#, is likely to mature further by 2025. With the rising popularity of WebAssembly (Wasm), Blazor could become central to creating lightweight, high-performing web applications.
Reason: WebAssembly adoption is broadening thanks to its ability to bring near-native performance to web applications. .NET will need Blazor to directly compete with JavaScript-based frameworks like React or Vue while gaining ground with C# expertise.
5. Game Development and Emerging Ecosystem Use Cases
The acquisition of Activision Blizzard emphasizes Microsoft‚Äôs interest in gaming. By 2025, .NET and C# may expand their foothold in game development, potentially challenging Unity (which relies on C#). At the same time, .NET could be increasingly used in IoT, VR/AR, and edge computing.
Reason: Gaming and immersive applications represent fertile ground for C#. Direct investments in this area align with Microsoft‚Äôs broader goals to diversify .NET usage.
Conclusion
By 2025, .NET and C# will likely evolve to become more cloud-native, smarter, and better optimized for performance across platforms. This evolution reflects Microsoft‚Äôs broader ambitions in cloud computing, AI, gaming, and developer productivity. With its strong community and enterprise focus, these technologies are poised to remain a force in modern software development.
Beep boop. ü§ñ
So that‚Äôs it! In a year‚Äôs time we‚Äôll know what‚Äôs accurate and what‚Äôs not. Keep in mind that gen AI is a statistical prediction algorithm, so it should be giving us statistically significant results. Only time will tell.

posts.creator: Alexey Totin
posts.title: Introducing CodeCanvas 2024.3
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
As we enter 2025, we hope you had an amazing holiday season filled with joy, relaxation, and plenty of inspiration for the year ahead!
CodeCanvas 2024.3, last year‚Äôs final release, went live just before the holidays. To avoid adding to the busy year-end rush, we delayed the announcement until now, ensuring it gets the attention it deserves. Now that the new year has begun, we‚Äôre excited to share the details of this release, which makes CodeCanvas an even more competitive tool for orchestrating cloud development environments (CDEs).
What‚Äôs new: The best of 2024.3
CodeCanvas 2024.3 is packed with new features and improvements. Here are some highlights.
Buy and manage licenses through your JetBrains account




Previously, the only way to buy and manage a CodeCanvas license was by contacting our sales team. Now, you can do it directly through your JetBrains account: buy, activate, renew, or add more users to your license ‚Äì all in just a few clicks!
Restrict copy/paste in JetBrains IDEs




For industries like fintech, healthcare, or any organization with strict security requirements, we‚Äôve introduced the ability to restrict copy/paste operations for JetBrains IDEs (copying code in a dev environment and pasting it locally). This ensures that sensitive data doesn‚Äôt leak to local machines.
Custom relay servers




This is our step toward multi-region support that lets you deploy relay servers (an intermediary between a local machine and a dev environment) closer to your dev environment clusters. This reduces latency and improves overall performance in multi-region setups.
Effortless Git integration




We‚Äôve simplified the process of connecting a Git repository to CodeCanvas. CodeCanvas can now auto-generate SSH keys when you add a repository connection. All you need to do is paste the public key to your Git hosting service, and you‚Äôre ready!
Other improvements
2024.3 includes many other great features, like setting session timeouts, installing IDE plugins from custom sources, enhancements for troubleshooting and logging, and others. Explore the full list on our What‚Äôs New page.
Learn more about CDEs
Curious why CDEs are the future of software and why they‚Äôre better than local machines and VDI? Check out our other blog posts:
Solving Remote Development Challenges With CodeCanvas: A CDE Orchestration Tool by JetBrains
Should Your Company Adopt Remote Development?
From VDI to CDEs: Solving Remote Development Challenges
To dive deeper into CodeCanvas, head over to our product page or documentation.
Thank you, and we hope your 2025 is off to a great start!

posts.creator: Jim Harrer
posts.title: Join us at VS Live! 2025 Las Vegas
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Join Your Favorite Speakers at VS Live! Las Vegas
With the new year here, many developers are looking for the best ways to stay ahead in a rapidly evolving tech landscape. That‚Äôs why Visual Studio Live! Las Vegas, March 10-14, 2025, is a must-attend event!
Stay ahead of the curve with the latest enhancements in .NET, Azure, GitHub, GitHub Copilot, Visual Studio, and more. Visual Studio Live! Las Vegas is your fastest way to catch up on the innovations shaping the tech landscape.
What Makes VS Live! Las Vegas a Must-Attend?¬†
From hands-on workshops to deep-dive sessions, this event is loaded with practical guidance you can apply immediately in your day-to-day development work. And I‚Äôm especially excited about our two powerhouse keynotes‚Äîwe‚Äôll explore the future of .NET, AI, and secure cloud-native data solutions.¬†
But that‚Äôs just the start. This year‚Äôs session lineup covers a huge spectrum, including:¬†
AI Development: See the latest for developers infusing their apps with AI leveraging LLMS, vector databases, and the latest SDKs to enhance developer. Also come see the latest enhancements in GitHub Copilot for AI assisted development.¬†
Mobile & Desktop App Development: Come learn how to build native Windows apps with WinUI 3 and the Windows App SDK, dive deep into native multi-platform development with .NET MAUI, and hybrid development across all platforms with Blazor Hybrid.¬†
.NET & C# Best Practices: Learn the newest .NET/C# features, bust common myths, and sharpen your skills in asynchronous programming, configuration, and more.¬†
SQL, Cosmos, Fabric, and AI: Dive into vector search, SQL integration with AI frameworks, the latest in CosmosDB, and data analysis in Fabric‚Äîdirectly from the team that builds them.¬† This will include details on the new release of SQL Server 2025 and SQL database in Fabric.¬†
Developer Well-Being & Leadership: Sessions on burnout, imposter syndrome, and team-building for remote developers‚Äîbecause our industry is about people as much as technology.¬†
Hands-On Labs: Roll up your sleeves in multi-day labs exploring Python & AI, .NET Aspire, SQL Server 2025, Blazor, and more‚Äîperfect for those who learn by doing.¬†
Two Keynotes You Won‚Äôt Want to Miss




Why I Think You‚Äôll Love This Conference¬†
Hands-On .NET & Azure Insights: There‚Äôs no better way to learn than by doing, and VSLive! is packed with demos, labs, and real-world examples.¬†
Expert Speakers & Networking: Rub elbows with Microsoft insiders, MVPs, and fellow Visual Studio developers. I‚Äôm always amazed by how many real-world problems get solved in hallway chats.¬†
Vegas Vibes & Big Ideas: After the sessions, explore the excitement of Las Vegas while solidifying the new connections you‚Äôve made.¬†
Ready to Register?¬†
Exclusive Discounts: If you have a Visual Studio Professional or Enterprise subscription, check my.visualstudio.com for exclusive discounts included with your subscription.¬†
Early Bird Deals: If you‚Äôre not a subscriber, save by registering early on the VSLive! Las Vegas event page. But hurry‚ÄîEarly Bird specials are ending soon.¬†
I‚Äôll be there, and I‚Äôd love to meet you to talk about all things Visual Studio, Azure, GitHub, AI, and more. Feel free to reach out with me via LinkedIn if you would like to meet during the conference.¬†¬†
Let‚Äôs make 2025 the year we elevate our skills together. Visual Studio Live! is more than a conference‚Äîit‚Äôs a community of developers learning, sharing, and growing. I can‚Äôt wait to see you there!
See you in Las Vegas!
LEARN MORE ABOUT VS LIVE! LAS VEGAS

posts.creator: Mryam Girmay
posts.title: Enhanced Change Signature in C++
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Change Signature allows you to modify a function‚Äôs parameters, including reordering, adding, removing, or altering them across various locations. Previously, the Change Signature feature in Visual Studio involved multiple clicks and nested pop-up windows. In Visual Studio 2022 version 17.12, we‚Äôve reduced the number of clicks and eliminated these nested steps to streamline the process.

Simplified Process with Intuitive Interface
We have updated the user interface for the Change Signature feature based on direct feedback we received from C++ developers to reduce the number of clicks and pop-up windows. It allows you to manage function parameters more efficiently by adding, removing, modifying and rearranging them directly in the parameter list editor. This layout allows you to see all your changes in one place, reducing the likelihood of errors.
This updated interface allows you to select and drag parameters to change their order to the desired position. This not only speeds up the process but also makes it easier to visualize and implement the changes.

Previous Change Signature UI:

Access Change Signature
To access the improved Change Signature feature, you can press Ctrl+. or right-click in the Visual Studio editor and select Quick Actions and Refactorings‚Ä¶ to open the Quick Actions and Refactoring menu. From there, select Change Signature to start making your modifications. This feature not only allows you to change the signature but also ensures that any parameter renames are reflected throughout the function. This access ensures you can make changes on-the-fly without disrupting your workflow.
Send us your Feedback
We are committed to continuous improvement based on your feedback. Your insights are invaluable, and we encourage you to keep sharing them with us using the Send Feedback button in Visual Studio, through the Developer Community, or via email at visualcpp@microsoft.com.
Stay connected with the Visual Studio team by following us on Twitter @VisualC, Twitter @VisualStudio, YouTube, and LinkedIn.
The post Enhanced Change Signature in C++ appeared first on Visual Studio Blog.

Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑú Ï°∞Í∏à Îçî Î≥¥ÏïàÏùÑ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ wheel Í∑∏Î£πÏóê ÏÜçÌïú Í≤ΩÏö∞ÏóêÎßå suÎ•º ÌóàÏö©ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù ÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§. ÌòπÏùÄ Í∑∏Î£πÏùÑ ÏÉàÎ°ú ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÏÑú Ìï¥Îãπ Í∂åÌïúÏùÑ Î∂ÄÏó¨ÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§. Î≥¥ÏïàÏùÑ Í∞ïÌïòÍ≤å ÌïòÎ†§Î©¥ wheelÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãå ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í∑∏Î£πÏùÑ ÎßåÎìúÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Î•º Ï∂îÏ≤úÌïúÎã§.
Ïù¥ Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÄ PAM(Pluggable Authentication Module)Ïùò pam_wheel.so Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÎ†§Î©¥ /etc/pam.d/su ÌååÏùºÏóê Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÏù¥ ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïúÎã§.

ÌäπÌûà session Î¶¨ÎçîÎ•º ÏùòÎØ∏ÌïòÎäî SIDÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Í≥µÎ∂ÄÎäî Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Ïûê ÎøêÎßå ÏïÑÎãàÎùº ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏ÎûòÎ®∏ÎèÑÏóêÍ≤åÎèÑ Îß§Ïö∞ Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Í∞úÎÖêÏù¥Îã§.

posts.content:
2023ÎÖÑ 1ÏõîÍ≤ΩÏóê LG U+ÏóêÏÑú Ìï¥ÌÇπ Ïπ®Ìï¥ ÏÇ¨Í≥†Í∞Ä Î∞úÏÉùÌñàÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏ Í≤∞Í≥º ÎßéÏùÄ Í≥†Í∞ùÏùò Ï†ïÎ≥¥Í∞Ä Ïú†Ï∂úÎêòÏóàÎäîÎç∞, Ï°∞ÏÇ¨ Í≤∞Í≥º ÏõêÏù∏ÏùÄ Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Ïûê Ïú†Ï†ÄÏùò ÏïîÌò∏Í∞Ä "admin"Ïù¥ÏóàÎã§Îäî Ï∂©Í≤©Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ïù¥ Î∞ùÌòÄÏ°åÎã§.

Ï∞∏Í≥† Í∏∞ÏÇ¨ - https://n.news.naver.com/mnews/article/047/0002390308

 

1. ÌòÑÏã§ÏóêÏÑúÏùò Ìï¥ÌÇπ

Ìï¥ÌÇπÏù¥ Îì±Ïû•ÌïòÎäî ÏòÅÌôîÎÇò ÎìúÎùºÎßàÎ•º Î≥¥Î©¥ Ï£ºÏù∏Í≥µÎì§ÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎãπ 1,000ÌÉÄ Ï†ïÎèÑÏùò ÌòÑÎûÄÌïú ÌÇ§Î≥¥Îìú ÌÉÄÏù¥ÌïëÍ≥º Ï∞ΩÏùÑ ÏóÑÏ≤≠ÎßéÏù¥ ÎùÑÏõåÎëêÍ≥† Í∏âÎ∞ïÌïòÍ≤å Ïπ®Ìà¨ÌïúÎã§. Î¨ºÎ°† ÌÇ§Î≥¥Îìú ÌôîÎ©¥ÏóêÏÑúÎäî Îπ†Î•∏ ÏÜçÎèÑÏùò Hello world Í∞ôÏùÄ Í∏∞Ï¥àÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏΩîÎìúÎì§ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÎäî ÏóâÏÑ±Ìï®Ïù¥ ÏûàÍ∏¥ ÌïòÎã§.

Í∑∏Îü¨ÎÇò ÏòÅÌôîÎÇò ÎìúÎùºÎßàÎäî ÌòÑÏã§Í≥º Îã§Î•¥Îã§. Ïã§ÏÉÅ Ìï¥ÌÇπÏùò ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÄ brute force attack, SQL injectionÏù¥ÎÇò ÏÇ¨ÌöåÍ≥µÌïôÌï¥ÌÇπÏù¥ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥Îã§. LG U+ Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≥≥Ïù¥ Îö´Î¶∞ Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÎåÄÌëúÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú brute force attackÏúºÎ°ú Îö´Î¶∞ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïù¥ Í≥µÍ≤©ÏùÄ Î≥ÑÎã§Î•∏Í≤å ÏïÑÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏ÎÉ• Î¨¥Ï∞®Î≥ÑÎ°ú ÏïîÌò∏Î•º ÎåÄÏûÖÌï¥Î≥¥Îäî Í≥µÍ≤©Ïù¥Îã§. ÎåÄÌëúÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú "00000", "qwer1234", "asdf1234", "q1w2e3r4", "admin", "asdfqwer" Îì±Îì± Í∞ÑÎã®Ìïú ÏïîÌò∏ ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏îÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜç ÏãúÎèÑÌï¥Î≥∏Îã§. Ïû¨Î∞åÍ≤åÎèÑ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÌïòÎ©¥ Î™áÎ™á ÏÑúÎ≤ÑÎì§ÏùÄ Í∞ÑÎã®ÌïòÍ≤å Îö´Î†§Î≤ÑÎ¶∞Îã§.

Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú ÌòÑÏã§ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÏùò Ìï¥ÌÇπÏùÄ Î©ãÏûàÍ≤å ÌÉÄÏù¥ÌïëÌïòÎäî Î™®ÏäµÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Í≥µÍ≤©Ìà¥ÏùÑ Î∞±Í∑∏ÎùºÏö¥ÎìúÏóêÏÑú Ïã§ÌñâÏãúÏºúÎëêÍ≥† Í∏∞Îã§Î¶¨Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Îü¨Îã§Í∞Ä Îö´Î¶¨Îäî Í≥≥Ïù¥ ÏûàÏúºÎ©¥ Ï†ëÏÜçÌï¥Î≥¥Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥†ÎÇòÏÑú root Í∂åÌïúÏùÑ ÌöçÎìùÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÌòπÏùÄ Í∞ÅÏ¢Ö ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò ÏïîÌò∏ÌÇ§Î•º ÌõîÏπòÎ†§Í≥† ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.

Î∞òÎåÄÎ°ú ÎßêÌïòÎ©¥ ÏïîÌò∏Î•º Î≥µÏû°ÌïòÍ≤å ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÏÑú Í¥ÄÎ¶¨ÌïòÎ©¥ Í±∞Ïùò Îö´Î¶¨ÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. 

Ïù¥Î≤àÏóê LG U+Í∞Ä Îö´Î†§ÏÑú ÎÇúÎ¶¨ÏòÄÏßÄÎßå Í≥ºÍ±∞ ÎÜçÌòëÎèÑ ÎπÑÏä∑ÌïòÍ≤å ÏïîÌò∏Í∞Ä ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Îã®ÏàúÌï¥ÏÑú Ìï¥ÌÇπÏùÑ ÎãπÌñàÏóàÎã§. Î™®ÎåÄÌïôÍµêÎèÑ ÏïîÌò∏Í∞Ä ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Îã®ÏàúÌï¥ÏÑú Îö´Î†∏ÏóàÎã§. Ïù¥Î†áÎìØ ÏïîÌò∏ Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Î•º Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÏïàÌï¥ÏÑú Îö´Î¶¨Îäî ÌöåÏÇ¨ÎÇò Í∏∞Í¥ÄÎì§Ïù¥ ÌïúÎëòÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎã§.

 

2. Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏïîÌò∏Í∞Ä ÏïàÏ†ÑÌïúÍ∞Ä?

ÏïîÌò∏Ïùò ÏïàÏ†ÑÏÑ±ÏùÑ ÌåêÎã®Ìï† Îïå Ï†úÏùº Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Í≤ÉÏùÄ Í∏∏Ïù¥ÏôÄ ÏïåÌååÎ≤≥ ÏàúÏÑú, ÏïåÎ†§ÏßÑ Îã®Ïñ¥Î•º Ïì∞ÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. ÌäπÌûà ÏïîÌò∏Ïùò Í∏∏Ïù¥Îäî ÏµúÏÜå 12Ïûê Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏóê Ïà´Ïûê, ÏïåÌååÎ≤≥, ÌäπÏàòÎ¨∏ÏûêÎ•º ÏÑûÏúºÎ©¥ brute force attackÏóêÏÑú 99.99% ÏïàÏ†ÑÌïòÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏïîÌò∏Î•º ÏïåÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÏßÅÏõêÏù¥ Ìá¥ÏÇ¨ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÏóêÎäî Íº≠ Ìå®Ïä§ÏõåÎìúÎ•º Î∞îÍøîÏïºÎßå ÌïúÎã§. ÏùòÏô∏Î°ú Ìá¥ÏÇ¨ÏûêÏóê ÏùòÌïú Ìï¥ÌÇπÏù¥ ÎπàÎ≤àÌïòÍ≤å Î∞úÏÉùÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.

Ï°∞Í∏à Îçî Î≥¥ÏïàÏù¥ Ï§ëÏöîÌïú ÌöåÏÇ¨ÎùºÎ©¥ OTPÎùºÎì†ÏßÄ FIDO2 Í∞ôÏùÄ Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ ÎèÑÏûÖÌïòÎ©¥ Îçî Ï¢ãÎã§.

Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏßÅÏõêÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å ÏïîÌò∏Î•º Ìè¨Ïä§Ìä∏ÏûáÏúºÎ°ú Ïç®ÏÑú Ï±ÖÏÉÅÏù¥ÎÇò ÏùòÏûê Î∞ëÏóê Î∂ôÏù¥ÏßÄ ÎßêÎùºÍ≥† ÍµêÏú°Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§. ÌäπÌûà Í≥µÍ∏∞ÏóÖÏù¥ÎÇò ÌïôÍµê Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≥≥ÏùÄ Î™®ÎãàÌÑ∞ Îí§Ï™ΩÏù¥ÎÇò, ÏùòÏûê, Ï±ÖÏÉÅÏùÑ Îí§ÏßëÏúºÎ©¥ ÏïîÌò∏Í∞Ä Ïç®ÏûàÎäî Ï™ΩÏßÄÍ∞Ä Î∂ôÏñ¥ÏûàÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÏßÑÏßú ÌóàÎã§ÌïòÎã§.

Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† SQL injectionÏùÄ ÏßÑÏßú Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÎäî Îã®Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑú Ï°∞Í∏àÎßå Ïã†Í≤ΩÏì∞Î©¥ Ìï¥Í≤∞Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÎä•Ìïú Î¨∏Ï†úÏù∏Îç∞, Ïù¥Í±∏ ÏïàÌïòÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§ÎèÑ ÎßéÎã§. ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÌï† Îïå SQL injection Î∞©Ïñ¥Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Íº≠ Ïã†Í≤ΩÏç®ÏÑú ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùÑ Í∞úÎ∞úÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§.

 

3. ÏïîÌò∏Î•º Ï†ÄÏû•ÌïòÎäî Î∞©Î≤ï

ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùÑ ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÌï† Îïå ÏïîÌò∏Î•º plain textÎ°ú Ï†ÄÏû•ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÄ Îß§Ïö∞ ÏúÑÌóòÌïú ÌñâÎèôÏù¥Îã§. ÏïîÌò∏Îäî Î¨¥Ï°∞Í±¥ hashÎêú Í∞íÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ÄÏû•Ìï¥ÏïºÎßå ÌïòÎ©∞, Í∑∏ ÏûêÏ≤¥Î•º hashÌïòÍ∏∞Î≥¥Îã§Îäî saltÏôÄ Ïó¨Îü¨Î≤à Ìï¥ÏãúÎ•º Î∞òÎ≥µÌï¥ÏÑú Ïú†Ï∂îÌï† Ïàò ÏóÜÎèÑÎ°ù Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ saltÎèÑ Ïß§ÎùºÏÑú Î∞òÏ†àÏùÑ Î®ºÏ†Ä ÎçîÌï¥ÏÑú 10Î≤àÏùÑ hashÌïòÍ≥† Í∑∏ Îã§Ïùå Î∞òÏ†àÏùÑ ÎçîÌï¥ÏÑú Î™áÏã≠Î≤àÏùÑ Îçî hashÎ•º ÌïòÎ©¥ Ìï¥ÏãúÍ∞íÏùÑ Î≥¥Í≥† ÏõêÎûò Í∞íÏùÑ ÏïåÏïÑÎÇ¥Í∏∞Îäî ÌûòÎì§Îã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ìï¥ÏïºÎßå ÎÇ¥Î∂ÄÏûêÏùò ÏÜåÌñâÏúºÎ°ú ÏïîÌò∏ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§Í∞Ä Ïú†Ï∂úÎêú Í≤ΩÏö∞Ïóê Ìï¥ÌÇπÏùÑ Î∞©Ïñ¥ Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§.

 

4. Í∑∏ Ïô∏Ïùò Î≥¥Ïïà

Ïù¥ Ïô∏Ïóê Î∞©ÌôîÎ≤ΩÏùÑ ÌÜµÌïú IPÏ∞®Îã®, Î°úÍ∑∏Ïù∏ Ïã§Ìå® ÌöüÏàòÏóê Îî∞ÎùºÏÑú Ï∞®Îã®ÌïòÍ∏∞, Ïô∏Î∂Ä ÏÑ§Ïπò ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû® ÎßâÍ∏∞ Ï†ïÎèÑÎäî ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Í¥ÄÎ¶¨ÏûêÍ∞Ä Íº≠ ÎèÑÏûÖÌï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî Í∏∞Îä•Ïù¥Îã§. ÌäπÌûà Ïô∏Î∂ÄÏóêÏÑú Îû©ÌÉë(ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Î∂Å)ÏùÑ Îì§Í≥† Îì§Ïñ¥Ïò§Îäî ÏßÅÏõêÎì§ Ï§ëÏóê Ïù¥ÏÉÅÌïú ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû® ÏÑ§ÏπòÌï¥ÏÑú ÏÇ¨Í≥†Î•º ÏπòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÍΩ§ ÎßéÎã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú Î™áÎ™á Î≥¥ÏïàÏù¥ ÍπåÎã§Î°úÏö¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§ÏùÄ Ïô∏Î∂ÄÏóêÏÑú Îû©ÌÉëÏùÑ Îì§Í≥† Ïò§Îäî ÏßÅÏõêÎì§ÏùÄ Îß•Î∂Å, Î¶¨ÎàÖÏä§Îßå Ïì∞ÎèÑÎ°ù Í∞ïÏ†úÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÎèÑ ÎßéÎã§. (ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò Í∞êÏóºÏùÄ ÏúàÎèÑ Ïª¥Ìì®ÌÑ∞Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ÏÑú ÏùºÏñ¥ÎÇòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§)

Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ï°∞Í∏à Îçî Î≥¥ÏïàÏùÑ Ï±ôÍ∏∞ÏûêÎ©¥ DDoS Î∞©Ïñ¥ÌïòÎäî Ï†ÑÎûµÎèÑ ÏßúÎëêÎäîÍ≤å Ï¢ãÎã§. DDoS Í≥µÍ≤©ÏùÄ ÏßÅÏ†ëÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ïú†Ï∂ú ÌîºÌï¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùº ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ Î∂àÍ∞ÄÎ°ú ÏñªÎäî ÌîºÌï¥Ïù¥Í≥†, Î∞©Ïñ¥ÌïòÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Îçî ÍπåÎã§Î°≠Îã§. Cloudflare ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎèÑ Î∞©Î≤ïÏù¥ÏßÄÎßå, ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÌï† Îïå ÌäπÏ†ï IPÏóêÏÑú ÌäπÏ†ï ÏãúÍ∞ÑÎåÄÏóê ÎßéÏù¥ Ï†ëÏÜçÌïúÎã§Îì†ÏßÄ, ÌòπÏùÄ keepaliveÎ•º Ïù¥Ïö©Ìï¥ÏÑú Ï†ëÏÜç ÌõÑ ÏïÑÎ¨¥ÏßìÎèÑ ÏïàÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ ÏßàÏßà ÎÅàÎã§Îì†ÏßÄ ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎì§ÏùÑ Í∞êÏßÄÌï¥ÏÑú Ï∞®Îã®Ìï† ÌïÑÏöîÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎã§.

Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ìï≠ÏÉÅ Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Îäî Î∞±ÏóÖÏùÑ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå sftp, Ïä§ÌÜ†Î¶¨ÏßÄ, NASÍ∞ôÏùÄ Í≤ÉÏúºÎ°ú Îã§Ïù¥Î†âÌä∏ Î∞±ÏóÖÌïòÎäî ÏßìÏùÄ Îß§Ïö∞ ÏúÑÌóòÌïòÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Î©¥ ÏÑúÎ≤ÑÍ∞Ä ÌÑ∏Î¶¨Î©¥ Î∞±ÏóÖ ÏÑúÎ≤ÑÎÇò Ïä§ÌÜ†Î¶¨ÏßÄ, NASÍπåÏßÄ Ï§ÑÏ§ÑÏù¥ ÌÑ∏Î¶∞Îã§. Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎπÑÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏÉÅÌô©ÏùÑ ÎßâÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ Î∞±ÏóÖÏùÑ ÏúÑÌïú Ï†ÑÏö© ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º Í∞ÑÎã®ÌïòÍ≤å Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÍ≥†, ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Ïú†Ï†ÄÏùò ÏïîÌò∏ÎÇò key ÏóÜÏù¥, ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû® Î†àÎ≤®ÏóêÏÑúÏùò Ìï¥ÏãúÎêú ÏïîÌò∏Î°ú Îã®Î∞©Ìñ• Î∞±ÏóÖÎßå Î∞õÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÎèÑÎ°ù ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§.(ÏïåÎ†§ÏßÑ Ìà¥ÏùÑ Ïì∞Îäî Í≤ÉÎ≥¥Îã§ ÏßÅÏ†ë Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÎäîÍ≤å Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ Î≥¥ÏïàÏù¥ Îçî ÎÜíÎã§. posts.title: Dev ToyÎ•º ÏßÄÏÜçÌïòÎäî Ïù¥Ïú†
posts.content:
ÏãúÎãàÏñ¥ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûê

  • Ìä∏Î†åÎîîÌïúÍ≤ÉÍ≥º, Î°úÏö∞ Î†àÎ≤® ÍπäÏù¥ÏôÄ, Í≤ΩÌóòÏùò Í∑†ÌòïÏùÑ Ïû°Í≥† Ìï©Î¶¨Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÌåêÎã®ÏùÑ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§.
  • Ïù¥ Í∑†ÌòïÏùÑ ÎÜìÏπòÍ∏∞ ÏãúÏûëÌïòÎ©¥, ÌåÄÏõêÎì§Ïùò Í≥µÍ∞êÏùÑ Î™ªÏñªÍ≥†, Í≤∞Íµ≠ Îí§Ï≥êÏßÄÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Î•º ÎßéÏù¥ Î¥Ñ
  • Í≤ΩÏüÅÎ†•ÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌûà Î∞úÏ†ÑÌïòÍ≥†, ÏÑ±Ïû•Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÍ∞Ä ÌèâÏÉù Í≥µÎ∂Ä Ìï¥Ïïº ÎêúÎã§Îäî Í∞úÎÖê

Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎÇò?

Ï≤†Ï†ÄÌûà Ïû¨ÎØ∏

  • ÎàÑÍ∞Ä ÏïàÏãúÏºúÎèÑ ÏßÄÏÜç Í∞ÄÎä•
  • Í∑∏ÎÉ• Ïû¨Î∞åÏúºÎãàÍπå, Ïö∞ÏÑ† ÏàúÏúÑÍ∞Ä ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§Î†à ÎÜíÏïÑÏßê
    • ÎßåÏïΩ ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§Î†à Ïïà ÎÜíÏïÑÏßÄÎ©¥, Îã§Î•∏ ÏùºÏù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎßéÏïÑÏÑú ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏóÜÍ±∞ÎÇò, Í∑∏ Ï†ïÎèÑ Ïû¨Î∞åÎäîÍ±¥ ÏïÑÎãåÍ≤É

      ÏóÖÎ¨¥Ï†Å Ïó≠Îüâ Í∞úÎ∞ú

  • Ïñ¥Îñ†Ìïú ÏóÖÎ¨¥ Î∞©Ìñ•Ïù¥ ÏûàÏùÑ Îïå, Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º Ìï¥Í≤∞ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑú Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Îñ†Ïò¨Î¶¥ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Î≤îÏ£º ÎÇ¥ÏóêÏÑú Í≤∞Î°†ÏùÑ ÎÉÑ
    • Ïù¥ Î≤îÏ£ºÎ•º ÎÑìÌûàÎäî Í≤É
  • ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏóÖÎ¨¥ÏóêÏÑú Î™®Îì† Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ, Îã§ Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÏùå
    • ÏóÖÎ¨¥Îäî Î∂ÑÎã¥Ìï† Ïàò Î∞ñÏóê ÏóÜÍ≥†, Î∂ÑÎã¥Ìï¥ÏÑú ÏßÑÌñâÌïú Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑÎäî Îî∞Îùº Ïû°ÏïÑÏïº Îê®
      • Î¶¨Î∑∞ÎèÑ ÌïòÍ≥†, ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÎèÑ ÌïòÍ≥†, QA ÎåÄÏùëÎèÑ Í∞ôÏù¥ ÌïòÍ≤å Îê† ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÏùå
      • ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§Î∂ÄÌÑ∞ Íµ¨ÌòÑÌïú Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑ ÎßåÌÅºÏùÄ ÏïÑÎãò
        • Í≤∞Íµ≠ ÎÇòÎäî ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ Îì§Ïó¨ÏÑú Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑÎ•º ÎÅåÏñ¥ Ïò¨Î¶¨Îäî ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏Î•º Ìï¥Ïïº Ìï®
  • ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í∏∞Ïà†Ïùò ÎèÑÏûÖ ÌòπÏùÄ Í∞úÏÑ† Î∞©Ìñ•
    • ÏóÖÎ¨¥Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ Î∞∞Ï†ï Î∞õÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏúºÎ©¥ ÎÇòÏù¥Ïä§ Ìï®
      • ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÌòÑÏã§Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Î¶¨ÏÑúÏπòÏóê ÏùºÏ†ïÏù¥ Ï£ºÏñ¥ÏßÄÎäî ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏù¥ ÎÇ¥ Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏúºÎ°ú ÏïÑÏ£º ÎßéÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÏùå
    • ÌÜ†Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏ÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥ÎäêÏ†ïÎèÑ Í≤∞Î°†ÏùÑ ÎÇ¥Ïïº, Ïù¥ Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ïñ¥Îñ§ Î∞©Ìñ•ÏúºÎ°ú Ìï¥Ïïº ÎêòÎäîÏßÄ Ïïå Ïàò ÏûàÎã§
      • Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Ï°∞Í∏à ÏïÑÏâ¨Ïö¥ ÌÄÑÎ¶¨Ìã∞ÎùºÎèÑ, ÏûêÏã†ÎßåÏùò Í≤∞Î°†ÏùÑ ÎÇ¥Ïïº Ìï®

Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ïù¥ Í≤ÉÎì§ÏùÑ ÏóÖÎ¨¥ ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Ïù¥Ïô∏Ïóê ÌïòÎäîÍ∞Ä?

  • Ï†ÑÏ†ú Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÑ ÍπîÍ≤†Ïùå
    • Ï†ÄÎèÑ ÌÅ¨Îü∞Ïπò ÎπàÎèÑÍ∞Ä ÎÜíÍ≥†, Ï£ºÎßê Ï∂úÍ∑ºÍπåÏßÄ Ìï† ÎïåÎäî Î™ªÌï©ÎãàÎã§
    • Ï†ÅÏñ¥ÎèÑ 8~10ÏãúÏóêÎäî Ìá¥Í∑ºÌïòÎäîÍ≤å Ìå®ÌÑ¥Ïù∏ ÏãúÍ∏∞Ïóê Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï®
      • Ï£ºÎßêÎèÑ Ïâ¨Ïñ¥Ï§òÏïº‚Ä¶ Ïó¨Î†•ÎèÑ ÏÉùÍ∏∞Í≥† Ïª®ÎîîÏÖòÎèÑ Í¥úÏ∞ÆÏïÑÏÑú Í∞ÄÎä•ÌñàÏùå

Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÌñàÎÉê?

  • ÎÇòÎäî ÏµúÏÜå ÎßàÏßÄÎÖ∏ÏÑ†Ïù¥ 1ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥Í≥†, ÏõêÌïòÎäî Î™©ÌëúÎ•º Îã¨ÏÑ±ÌïòÎ©¥ Îπ®Î¶¨ ÎÅùÎÇ¥Í≥†, Ïû¨Î∞åÏúºÎ©¥ Îçî Í∏∏Í≤åÌï®
  • Ïù¥ Dev ToyÏïåÎ¶ºÏù¥ Ìï≠ÏÉÅ Ï†ÄÏóêÍ≤å ÎÖ∏Ïù¥Ï¶àÎ°úÏç® ÏûëÏö©Ìï¥Ïïº ÌïòÍ≥† Snooze Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÏñ¥Ïïº ÌñàÏùå
    • Ïù¥ Dev ToyÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï†ÄÏóêÍ≤å ÎßåÌÅº ÌîÑÎ°úÎãµÏßÄ Î™ªÌïú, ÏãúÎãàÏñ¥ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûê ÎãµÏßÄ Î™ªÌïú ÏûêÏÑ∏ÎùºÍ≥† Í∑úÏ†ïÏßÄÏóàÏùå
      • ÏÇ¨Ïã§ Dev Toy Ïïà ÌïòÎäî ÏãúÎãàÏñ¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÏ£º ÎßéÏùå
      • ÎÇ®Îì§ÎèÑ ÏïàÌïòÎãàÍπå ÎÇòÎèÑ ÏïàÌï¥ÎèÑ Í¥úÏ∞ÆÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï§ëÏöîÌï®
      • ÏÇ¨Ïã§ Ïó¨Í∏∞ÍπåÏßÄ Ïò§Í∏∞ Ï†ÑÏóê Ï¶êÍ±∞ÏõÄÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ ÎäêÍª¥Ïïº Ìï®
        • Ï¶êÍ±∞Ïö¥ Ìûò, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏûêÏú®Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏïïÎ∞ïÏù¥ Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌï®ÏúºÎ°ú ÏπòÌôòÎê† Ïàò ÏûàÏùå
  • Ï∂úÌá¥Í∑º ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏóê Dev ToyÏùò Î∞©Ìñ•ÏÑ±ÏùÑ Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜç Ìï®
    • Î≠ò Ìï† Í≤ÉÏù∏Í∞Ä?
    • Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï† Í≤ÉÏù∏Í∞Ä?
    • Ï∂úÌá¥Í∑º ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏóêÎäî ÏûêÎ£å ÏùΩÍ∏∞Îäî Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌûà Ìï®
    • Ï∂úÌá¥Í∑º ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏóê ÏΩîÎî©ÏùÑ Ìïú Ï†ÅÎèÑ ÏûàÏúºÎÇò, Î≤ÑÏä§Í∞Ä ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Î∂àÌé∏ÌïòÍ≥† ÏòÜÏûêÎ¶¨Ïóê ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Ï§òÏÑú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏùÑ Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ≥†, Î¶¨ÏÑúÏπò ÌïòÎäî Í≤É ÏúÑÏ£ºÎ°úÎßå ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏùå
  • ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Î®º ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏Îäî Ï†àÎåÄ ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÏùå
    • Ìïú ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Îã®ÏúÑÎ°ú Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ•º ÎÇº Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Îã®ÏúÑÎ°ú ÏùºÏùÑ Ï™ºÍ∞§ Ïàò ÏóÜÏúºÎ©¥ ÏßÑÌñâÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏùå
    • Í∞ÅÏù¥ ÏïàÏû°ÌûàÎäî Î∞©Ìñ•ÏÑ±ÏùÄ 1ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùÄ Ïì∞ÏßÄ ÏïäÏùå
  • ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ Í∏∞Ïà† ÌïôÏäµ
    • Ï≤†Ï†ÄÌûà Best PracticeÎ•º Îî∞Îùº Í∞îÍ≥†, ÌóàÎì§Ïù¥ ÏÉùÍ∏∏ÎßåÌïú ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùÄ, Ïù¥ Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑÍ∞Ä ÎÜíÏïÑÏßÄÍ≥† ÎÇòÏÑú Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÍ≤å Ïú†ÎèÑÌï®
    • ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ïñ∏Ïñ¥ Î∞∞Ïö∏ Îïê ÌôòÍ≤Ω Íµ¨ÏÑ± Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï¢Ä ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ Í±∏Î¶º
      • ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ Í±∏Î¶¨Îäî Îç∞ÎìúÎùºÏù∏ÏùÑ Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥† Ïù¥Î•º ÎÑòÏñ¥ÏÑúÎ©¥ ÌïôÏäµ ÎåÄÏÉÅÏóêÏÑú Îπ†Î•¥Í≤å Î∞∞Ï†ú
    • Ïñ¥Îñ†Ìïú ÌïôÏäµÏóê ÌóàÎì§Ïù¥ ÎßéÏù¥ Ïò§Îäî Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÄ Dev ToyÎ•º Î∂ÄÎã¥Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å ÎßåÎì†Îã§Í≥† Í∑úÏ†ïÌï®
      • ÌóàÎì§Ïù¥ ÎßéÏù¥ Í±∏Î¶¥ ÏàòÎ°ù Îí§Î°ú (ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏùÄ Í±∞Ïùò Î∞ò Ïù¥ÏÉÅ ÌèêÍ∏∞) ÎØ∏Î£∏
        • ÎÇ¥ Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑ ÎïåÎ¨∏ Ïùº ÏàòÎèÑ, Ìï¥Îãπ Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ÎÇò, Ìå®ÌÇ§ÏßÄÍ∞Ä ÏÑ±ÏàôÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌï¥ÏÑúÏùº ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÏùå
          • Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ΩÏö∞Îçò ÌóàÎì§Ïù¥ ÎßéÏù¥ ÎäêÍª¥ÏßÄÎ©¥ Î∞îÎ°ú ÌèêÍ∏∞
    • Î¨¥Ïñ∏Í∞Ä Íµ¨ÌòÑÏùÑ Ìï† Îïå, Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï¥Ïïº Îê†ÏßÄ Í∞êÏù¥ ÏïàÏû°ÌûàÎ©¥ Ï†àÎåÄ ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÏùå
      • Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Í≥†ÎØºÏùÄ ÏóÖÎ¨¥ÎÇò, ÏùºÎ∂Ä ÎèÑÏ†Ñ Ï£ºÏ†úÏóê Í∞ÄÍπåÏö¥ ÌÅ∞ ÎßòÎ®πÍ≥† Ìï¥Ïïº ÎêòÎäî ÏùºÎ∂Ä Ï£ºÏ†ú ÌïúÏ†ïÏûÑ
      • Í∏∞Î≥∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Íµ¨ÌòÑÌï¥Î≥¥Í≥†, Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ Ìï¥Î≥¥Í≥†, Ïñ¥Îñ†Ìïú Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑÎ•º ÎÜíÏùº Í≤ÉÏù∏ÏßÄÍ∞Ä Ï∂îÏÉÅÏ†ÅÏù¥Î©¥, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Í∑∏Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í≤∞Î°†ÎÇ¥Í∏∞ Ï†ÑÍπåÏßÄÎäî TO DO ÏÉÅÌÉúÎ°úÎßå Ïú†ÏßÄÌï®
        • TO DO ÏÉÅÌÉúÏóê Ïò§Îûò ÎÇ®ÏùÄ Ï£ºÏ†úÎäî archiveÎ°ú Î≥¥ÎÉÑ

Í∑∏ÎûòÎèÑ Ïûò ÏïàÎêòÎäî ÏãúÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÏûàÏùå

  • Ïù¥Îü¥ ÎïåÎäî Í∏∞Ï°¥Ïóê ÎßåÎì§ÏóàÎçò Toy ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏Î•º Ìè¥Î¶¨Ïã±ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò
  • ÏßÑÏßú Ïû¨Î∞åÎäî ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎßåÎìúÎäî ÏÜåÌíà ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏ Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≤ÉÎßå Ìï®
  • ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïç®Î®πÎäî Ï†úÌíàÏùÑ ÎßåÎìúÎäî Í≤å Ï†úÏùº Ï¢ãÏùå
    • Í∏∞Ï°¥ Ï†úÌíàÏù¥ Ïñ¥Îñ§ Ïù¥Ïú†ÏóêÏÑúÍ±¥ Î∂ÄÏ°±Ìï®Ïù¥ ÏûàÏñ¥ÏÑú, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Í∞úÏÑ† Ìï¥Ïïº ÎêòÎäîÎç∞, Ìï¥Îãπ Ï†úÌíà ÎßåÎì†ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎßå Í∞úÏÑ†Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÏÉÅÌô©Ïùº ÎïåÍ∞Ä Ï¢ãÏïòÏùå
  • ÏÑ±Ï∑®Í∞êÏùÑ ÎäêÍª¥Ïïº Ìï®
    • Ïù¥ ÌñâÏúÑÍ∞Ä Ïû¨ÎØ∏, Ïπ¥ÌÉÄÎ•¥ÏãúÏä§Î•º Î™ª ÏùºÏúºÌÇ§Î©¥ ÏßÄÏÜçÏÑ±ÏûàÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄ
    • Ï†ÅÏñ¥ÎèÑ ÏûêÏã†ÏùÄ ÎßåÏ°± ÏãúÏºúÏïº Ìï®
    • Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú, ÎÇòÎäî Î∞±ÏóîÎìú Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÏßÄÎßå, ÏãúÍ∞ÅÏ†Å ÏûêÍ∑πÏùÑ Ï§Ñ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÏàòÎã®ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ï°∞ ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ï¢ãÏïÑÌï®

posts.author: Ïñ¥Îñ§Ïò§ÌõÑÏùò ÌîÑÎ¶¨Ïõ®Ïñ¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞
posts.content:
ÏÇ¨Îûå ÎÉÑÏÉà ÎÇòÎäî AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞, Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï†ÍπåÏöî? Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÎßåÎì† Ï±óÎ¥á, GPTSÍ∞Ä Î∞îÎ°ú Í∑∏ ÎãµÏûÖÎãàÎã§! ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≥† Í≥µÍ∞ê Í∞ÄÎäî Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÎßåÎìúÎäî ÎπÑÎ≤ïÏùÑ ÏßÄÍ∏à ÌôïÏù∏Ìï¥ Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî.

 

Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂Ñ, AIÍ∞Ä ÎßåÎì† Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÏùΩÏùÑ Îïå ÎäêÎÇåÏù¥ Ïñ¥Îñ†ÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî? Ïûò Ïì∞Í∏¥ ÌñàÏßÄÎßå Î≠îÍ∞Ä Í∏∞Í≥ÑÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÎÉÑÏÉàÍ∞Ä ÎÇòÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÏßÄ ÏïäÏúºÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî? ÏÇ¨Ïã§ Ï†ÄÎèÑ Ï≤òÏùåÏóî AI Í∏ÄÏùÑ Î≥¥Î©∞ "Ïù¥Í±∏ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏ≤òÎüº ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å Î∞îÍæ∏Î†§Î©¥ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏñºÎßàÎÇò Í±∏Î¶¥Íπå?" Í≥†ÎØºÌïòÍ≥§ ÌñàÏñ¥Ïöî. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Í∑∏ Í≥†ÎØºÏùÑ Ìï¥Í≤∞ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÏßÅÏ†ë 'Ïù∏Í∞ÑÎÉÑÏÉà' GPTSÎ•º ÎßåÎì§Í≤å ÎêòÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Ï±óÎ¥áÏùÄ Îã®ÏàúÌïú AI ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÏÉùÏÑ±Í∏∞Î•º ÎÑòÏñ¥, Í∏ÄÏóê ÏßÑÏ†ïÏÑ±Í≥º Í∞êÏ†ïÏùÑ Îã¥ÏïÑÏ£ºÎäî Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ Ìï¥Ïöî. Ïò§ÎäòÏùÄ Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÎßåÎì† Ïù¥ Ï±óÎ¥áÏùò ÎπÑÎ∞ÄÏùÑ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÍªò ÏÜåÍ∞úÌïòÎ†§Í≥† Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

 

Ïôú GPTSÎ•º ÎßåÎì§ÏóàÎÇòÏöî?

AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞Ïùò ÌïúÍ≥Ñ

Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ï≤òÏùå AIÍ∞Ä ÏûëÏÑ±Ìïú Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ï†ëÌñàÏùÑ Îïå, ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ Í∏∞Ïà†Î†•Ïóê Í∞êÌÉÑÌñàÏßÄÎßå, Î≠îÍ∞Ä Î∂ÄÏ°±ÌïòÎã§Îäî ÎäêÎÇåÏù¥ Îì§ÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî. Ï†ïÌôïÌûà ÎßêÌïòÎ©¥, Í∏ÄÏóê ÏÇ¨Îûå ÎÉÑÏÉàÍ∞Ä ÏóÜÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÏùΩÏùÑ Îïå ÎäêÎÅºÎäî Îî∞ÎúªÌï®, Í≥µÍ∞ê, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º Îì£Îäî ÎìØÌïú Ìé∏ÏïàÌï®Ïù¥ Îπ†Ï†∏ ÏûàÏóàÏ£†.

ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, AIÎäî "Ïù¥ ÎèÑÏãúÎäî ÏïÑÎ¶ÑÎãµÎã§"ÎùºÍ≥† Ïì∏ Ïàò ÏûàÏßÄÎßå, "Ïù¥ ÎèÑÏãúÏùò Ìï¥Î≥ÄÏóêÏÑú Î∞îÎùºÎ≥∏ ÏÑùÏñëÏùÄ ÎßàÏπò Ìô©Í∏àÎπõ Î¨ºÍ≤∞ Í∞ôÏïòÏñ¥Ïöî"ÎùºÎäî ÏãùÏùò Í∞êÏÑ±Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î¨òÏÇ¨Îäî Ïûò ÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú Ïù¥Îü∞ Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º Ìï¥Í≤∞ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎèÖÏûêÏùò ÎßàÏùåÏùÑ ÏõÄÏßÅÏù¥Í≥†, ÏßÑÏßú ÎåÄÌôîÎ•º ÎÇòÎàÑÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÏùÄ Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Ï£ºÎäî GPTSÎ•º Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÍ≤å ÎêòÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

 

 

GPTS Ï±óÎ¥áÏùò Ï£ºÏöî Í∏∞Îä•

Ô∏è 1. ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏ≤òÎüº ÎßêÌïòÍ∏∞

GPTSÏùò Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ ÌäπÏßïÏùÄ ÎåÄÌôîÌïòÎìØÏù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïì∏ Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥ÏóêÏöî. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "Ïö¥ÎèôÏùÄ Í±¥Í∞ïÏóê Ï¢ãÏäµÎãàÎã§"ÎùºÎäî Îî±Îî±Ìïú Î¨∏Ïû•ÏùÑ "Ï†úÍ∞Ä Îß§Ïùº ÏïÑÏπ® Ïä§Ìä∏Î†àÏπ≠ÏùÑ 10Î∂ÑÏî© ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞Ïöî, ÎçïÎ∂ÑÏóê ÌïòÎ£®Í∞Ä Ìõ®Ïî¨ Í∞ÄÎ≥çÍ≤å ÏãúÏûëÎêòÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî!"Ï≤òÎüº Î∞îÍøÄ Ïàò ÏûàÎãµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎåÄÌôîÏ≤¥Î°ú Ï†ÑÌôòÌïòÎ©¥ Í∏ÄÏù¥ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî Îî∞ÎúªÌïòÍ≥† ÏπúÍ∑ºÌïòÍ≤å ÎäêÍª¥Ï†∏Ïöî.

 

2. Í∞êÍ∞ÅÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î¨òÏÇ¨ Ï∂îÍ∞Ä

ÏÇ¨Îûå ÎÉÑÏÉà ÎÇòÎäî Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ Í∞ÄÏû• Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Í±¥ Í∞êÍ∞ÅÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î¨òÏÇ¨ÏòàÏöî. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "ÎßõÏûàÎäî ÏùåÏãù"Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Îã®Ïñ¥ ÎåÄÏã†, "Î≤ÑÌÑ∞Ïùò Í≥†ÏÜåÌïú Ìñ•Ïù¥ ÌçºÏßÄÍ≥†, Í∞ì Íµ¨Ïö¥ ÎπµÏóêÏÑú Ïò¨ÎùºÏò§Îäî Îî∞ÎúªÌïú ÍπÄÏù¥ ÎäêÍª¥ÏßÄÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî"ÎùºÎäî ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú Í∏ÄÏóê ÏÉùÎèôÍ∞êÏùÑ ÎçîÌïòÎäî Í±∞Ï£†. GPTSÎäî Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎîîÌÖåÏùºÌïú ÌëúÌòÑÏùÑ ÏûêÎèôÏúºÎ°ú ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Ï§òÏöî.

 

‚úçÔ∏è 3. Í∞úÏù∏ÌôîÎêú Ïä§ÌÜ†Î¶¨ÌÖîÎßÅ

ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÌóòÎã¥Ïóê Îçî Í¥ÄÏã¨ÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÄÏ£†. GPTSÎäî Ïù¥ Ï†êÏùÑ ÌôúÏö©Ìï¥ Í∏ÄÏóê ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º ÎÖπÏó¨Ï§çÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Í¥ÄÎ¶¨ Î∞©Î≤ï"Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Ï£ºÏ†úÎ•º "Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Í∞Ä ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõåÏÑú Í≥†ÎØºÌïòÎã§Í∞Ä ÏãúÏûëÌïú Î∞©Î≤ïÏù∏Îç∞Ïöî..."Ï≤òÎüº Í∞úÏù∏ÌôîÎêú Í≤ΩÌóòÏúºÎ°ú ÌíÄÏñ¥ÎÇº Ïàò ÏûàÍ≤å ÎèÑÏôÄÏ§òÏöî.

 

GPTSÏùò ÏûëÎèô ÏõêÎ¶¨

GPTSÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌïú AI ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÏÉùÏÑ±Í∏∞Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÏóêÏöî. Î™á Í∞ÄÏßÄ ÌäπÎ≥ÑÌïú ÏïåÍ≥†Î¶¨Ï¶òÍ≥º Ï†ÑÎûµÏù¥ ÎçîÌï¥Ï†∏ÏÑú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏ≤òÎüº ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§Îü¨Ïö¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÎÉÖÎãàÎã§.

  1. Ïä§ÌÜ†Î¶¨ÌÖîÎßÅ Í∏∞Î∞ò: ÎèÖÏûêÍ∞Ä Í≥µÍ∞êÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í∞úÏù∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í≤ΩÌóòÍ≥º ÏÉÅÌô©ÏùÑ Ï§ëÏã¨ÏúºÎ°ú Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÏûëÏÑ±Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.
  2. ÎåÄÌôîÌòï Ïñ¥Ìà¨ Ï†ÅÏö©: ÎßàÏπò ÏπúÍµ¨ÏôÄ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌïòÎäî ÎìØÌïú ÌÜ§ÏúºÎ°ú Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÏûëÏÑ±Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.
  3. Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÎîîÌÖåÏùº Ï∂îÍ∞Ä: ÏãúÍ∞Å, Ï≤≠Í∞Å, Ï¥âÍ∞Å Îì±ÏùÑ ÏûêÍ∑πÌïòÎäî ÏÑ∏Î∞ÄÌïú Î¨òÏÇ¨Î•º Ìè¨Ìï®Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

 

GPTSÎ°ú Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïû¨Íµ¨ÏÑ±ÌïòÎäî Î∞©Î≤ï

1. Í∏∞Ï°¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÎåÄÌôîÏ≤¥Î°ú Î≥ÄÌôò

posts.content:
Íµ¨Í∏Ä Í≤ÄÏÉâÏóêÏÑú ÏÇ¨ÎùºÏßÄÎäî Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Îì§, Î¨¥ÏóáÏù¥ Îã¨ÎùºÏ°åÏùÑÍπåÏöî? ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìòï AIÏùò Îì±Ïû•ÏúºÎ°ú Í≥µÏû•Ï≤òÎüº Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ Í∏∞ÏÇ¨Î•º ÎåÄÎüâÏúºÎ°ú Ï∞çÏñ¥ÎÇ¥Îäî ÏãúÎåÄÏóê Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏù¥ Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÎëêÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÑ ÌÖåÎãàÍπåÏöî.

 

"ÏïÑÎãà, ÏöîÏ¶ò Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑú Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ Í∏ÄÏù¥ Ïôú Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ïïà Î≥¥Ïù¥Îäî Í±∞Ï£†?

 

 Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Î•º Ïö¥ÏòÅÌïòÏãúÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ÎùºÎ©¥ Ìïú Î≤àÏØ§ Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≥†ÎØºÏùÑ ÌïòÏÖ®ÏùÑ Í≤É Í∞ôÏïÑÏöî. Ï†ÄÎèÑ Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Î•º Ïö¥ÏòÅÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏµúÍ∑º Î≥ÄÌôîÎ•º ÌîºÎ∂ÄÎ°ú ÎäêÎÅºÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞Ïöî. ÏòàÏ†ÑÏóêÎäî Í≤ÄÏÉâÌïòÎ©¥ ÏâΩÍ≤å Î≥¥Ïù¥Îçò Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ Í∏ÄÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî ÌïúÏ∞∏ÏùÑ ÎÇ¥Î†§Ïïº Î≥¥Ïù¥ÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî.

 

 ÌäπÌûà Ïû¨ÎØ∏ÏûàÎäî Í±¥. Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ ÏàòÏùµÌôî Í∞ïÏùòÌïòÏãúÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ (ÏÜåÏúÑ, Í∞ïÏùò ÌåîÏù¥Îùº Î∂àÎ¶¨Îäî) 1ÏõîÎßå ÎêòÎ©¥ "Îèà ÎêòÎäî ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìú"ÎùºÎ©¥ÏÑú "Ïã†ÎÖÑÏö¥ÏÑ∏"Î•º Ï∂îÏ≤úÌïòÎäî Í∞ïÏùòÎì§Ïù¥ ÏèüÏïÑÏßÄÏûñÏïÑÏöî? ÎßàÏπò ÎπÑÎ∞ÄÏä§Îü¨Ïö¥ Ï†ïÎ≥¥ÎùºÎèÑ ÎêòÎäî Í≤ÉÏ≤òÎüº ÎßêÏù¥Ï£†. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑú "Ïã†ÎÖÑÏö¥ÏÑ∏"Î•º Í≤ÄÏÉâÌï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥... Ïñ¥Îñ§Í∞ÄÏöî? Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Îäî Ï∞æÏïÑÎ≥¥Í∏∞ ÌûòÎì§Í≥† ÎåÄÌòï Ìè¨ÌÑ∏Ïù¥ÎÇò Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ Ïö¥ÏÑ∏ ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Îßå Í∞ÄÎìùÌïòÏ£†?

 

 Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏóêÍ≤å Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Îêú Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ ÏàòÏùµÌôî Î∞©Î≤ïÎ•º ÏïåÎ†§Ï£ºÎäî Í≤å ÏïÑÎãàÎü¨ ÏûêÏã†Îì§Ïùò ÏàòÏùµÌôîÎ•º Ï´ìÎã§ Î≥¥Îãà Ïù¥Îü∞ Í∏∞Î•òÎ•º Í∞êÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Í±∞Ï£†. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú "Í∞ïÏùò ÌåîÏù¥"Î°ú Ï†ÄÌèâÍ∞Ä ÎêòÏñ¥ Î≤ÑÎ¶¨Í≥†.... ÌòπÏãú Î™®Î•¥Ï£†. ÏïÑÎßà Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïñ¥Îäê 'Í∞ïÏùò ÌåîÏù¥'Î∂ÑÏù¥ Î≥∏Îã§Î©¥ Î∞îÎ°ú ÌÉúÏÑ∏ Ï†ÑÌôòÌï¥ÏÑú Í∞ïÏùò ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ ÏàòÏ†ïÌï†ÏßÄ.. „Öé„Öé

 

Ïôú Ïù¥Îü∞ Î≥ÄÌôîÍ∞Ä ÏùºÏñ¥ÎÇòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Í±∏ÍπåÏöî? Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏµúÍ∑º Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò Î≥ÄÌôîÎ•º Í¥ÄÏã¨ ÏûàÍ≤å Î≥¥Î©¥ÏÑú ÏïåÍ≤å Îêú ÎÇ¥Ïö©Îì§ÏùÑ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÍ≥º Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÎ†§Í≥† Ìï¥Ïöî. 

 

 

Ïôú Ïù¥Îü¥Íπå?

1. Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏù¥ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Î•º Î≥¥Îäî ÎààÏù¥ ÍπåÎã§Î°úÏõåÏ°åÏñ¥Ïöî

Îçî Ïù¥ÏÉÅ ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÎßå ÏûîÎú© ÎÑ£ÎäîÎã§Í≥† ÏÉÅÏúÑ ÎÖ∏Ï∂úÏù¥ ÎêòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïÑÏöî. Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò AIÍ∞Ä ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò ÌíàÏßàÏùÑ Ï†ïÎßê ÍººÍººÌûà Ï≤¥ÌÅ¨ÌïúÎãµÎãàÎã§. Ïã§Ï†ú Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥ÎÇò Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ÏÑ±Ïù¥ Îã¥Í∏¥ Í∏ÄÏù∏ÏßÄ, Îã®ÏàúÌûà Îã§Î•∏ Í≥≥Ïùò Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏòÆÍ≤® Îã¥ÏùÄ Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãåÏßÄ, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ AIÍ∞Ä ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìïú Í∏ÄÏùÄ ÏïÑÎãåÏßÄÍπåÏßÄ ÎòëÎòëÌïòÍ≤å Íµ¨Î∂ÑÌï¥ÎÇ∏Îã§Í≥† Ìï¥Ïöî.

 

Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏Ìï¥Î¥§ÎäîÎç∞Ïöî, Í∞ôÏùÄ Ï£ºÏ†úÎ°ú Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïç®ÎèÑ Ïã§Ï†ú Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ Î∞îÌÉïÏúºÎ°ú Ïì¥ Í∏ÄÍ≥º Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑ÏóêÏÑú Ï∞æÏùÄ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìïú Í∏ÄÏùò ÎÖ∏Ï∂ú Í≤∞Í≥ºÍ∞Ä ÌôïÏó∞Ìûà Îã¨ÎûêÏñ¥Ïöî. ÏßÑÏ†ïÏÑ± ÏûàÎäî ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Í∞Ä ÌôïÏã§Ìûà Ïö∞ÏúÑÎ•º Ï∞®ÏßÄÌïòÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî.

2. Ïã†Î¢∞ÎèÑÍ∞Ä ÏµúÏö∞ÏÑ† ÏàúÏúÑÍ∞Ä ÎêòÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî

Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùÄ Ïù¥Ï†ú Í≥µÏã†Î†• ÏûàÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º Ïö∞ÏÑ†Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï§òÏöî. Ï†ïÎ∂ÄÍ∏∞Í¥Ä, ÎåÄÍ∏∞ÏóÖ, Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ Ïñ∏Î°†ÏÇ¨ Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≥≥Ïùò ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Í∞Ä Í∞úÏù∏ Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Î≥¥Îã§ Ïö∞ÏÑ†ÏàúÏúÑÎ•º Í∞ÄÏ†∏Í∞ÄÎäî Í±∞Ï£†. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ Í±¥Í∞ï Í¥ÄÎ†® Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Í≤ÄÏÉâÌïòÎ©¥ Í∞úÏù∏ Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Î≥¥Îã§Îäî ÎåÄÌòï Î≥ëÏõêÏù¥ÎÇò Î≥¥Í±¥Î≥µÏßÄÎ∂Ä ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Í∞Ä Î®ºÏ†Ä ÎÇòÏò§Îäî ÏãùÏù¥ÏóêÏöî.

Ïù¥Í±¥ Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏù¥ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å Îçî Ï†ïÌôïÌïòÍ≥† Ïã†Î¢∞Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎ†§Îäî ÎÖ∏Î†•Ïùò ÏùºÌôòÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† Ìï¥Ïöî. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú ÏïÑÎ¨¥Î¶¨ Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïùò Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ Í∏ÄÏù¥ÎùºÎèÑ Í∏∞Í¥ÄÏù¥ÎÇò Í∏∞ÏóÖÏùò Í≥µÏãù ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÎ≥¥Îã§Îäî Îí§Î°ú Î∞ÄÎ¶¨Îäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÎßéÏïÑÏ°åÏ£†.

3. ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥ ÌïµÏã¨ ÏöîÏÜåÎ°ú Îñ†Ïò¨ÎûêÏñ¥Ïöî.

Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò ÏßàÎßåÌÅºÏù¥ÎÇò ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê Í≤ΩÌóòÎèÑ Ï§ëÏöîÌï¥Ï°åÏñ¥Ïöî. Aicolors.coÎäî AIÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï ÏÉâÏÉÅ ÌåîÎ†àÌä∏Î•º ÏâΩÍ≤å ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù ÎèÑÏôÄÏ£ºÎäî ÌòÅÏã†Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÎèÑÍµ¨Î°ú, Í∑∏ÎûòÌîΩ Î∞è Ïõπ ÎîîÏûêÏù¥ÎÑàÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å Ï∞ΩÏùòÏÑ±Í≥º Ìö®Ïú®ÏÑ±ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

 

 ÎîîÏûêÏù∏ ÏûëÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎã§ Î≥¥Î©¥ Í∞ÄÏû• Í≥†ÎØºÎêòÎäî Î∂ÄÎ∂Ñ Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä Î∞îÎ°ú ÏÉâÏÉÅ Ï°∞Ìï©ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏûòÎ™ªÎêú ÏÉâÏÉÅ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏùÄ ÎîîÏûêÏù∏Ïùò Î©îÏãúÏßÄÎ•º ÌùêÎ¶¨Í≤å ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò, Î∏åÎûúÎìú Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏóê Î∂ÄÏ†ïÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Ï§Ñ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Î∞òÎåÄÎ°ú, Ï†ÅÏ†àÌïú ÏÉâÏÉÅ ÌåîÎ†àÌä∏Î•º ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎ©¥ Î≥¥Îäî Ïù¥Ïùò Í∞êÏ†ïÏùÑ ÏûêÍ∑πÌïòÍ≥†, ÎîîÏûêÏù∏Ïùò Í∞ÄÏπòÎ•º ÎÜíÏù¥Îäî Îç∞ Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

 

Í∑∏Î†áÎã§Î©¥ Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏÉâÏÉÅ ÏÑ†ÌÉù Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÑ ÏûêÎèôÌôîÌï¥ Ï§Ñ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä ÏûàÎã§Î©¥ Ïñ¥Îñ®ÍπåÏöî? Î∞îÎ°ú Aicolors.coÍ∞Ä Í∑∏Îü¨Ìïú ÎèÑÍµ¨ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑúÎäî Aicolors.coÏùò Ï£ºÏöî Í∏∞Îä•Í≥º ÌôúÏö© Î∞©Î≤ï, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Í≤ΩÏüÅ ÎèÑÍµ¨ÏôÄ ÎπÑÍµêÌñàÏùÑ ÎïåÏùò Ïû•Ï†êÏùÑ Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

 

Aicolors.coÏùò Ï£ºÏöî Í∏∞Îä•

1. AI Í∏∞Î∞òÏùò ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï ÏÉâÏÉÅ ÌåîÎ†àÌä∏ ÏÉùÏÑ±

Aicolors.coÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌïú ÏÉâÏÉÅ ÏÉùÏÑ± ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãôÎãàÎã§. ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÍ∞Ä ÏûÖÎ†•Ìïú ÌÖåÎßàÎÇò ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÎ•º Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú AIÍ∞Ä ÏÉâÏÉÅ Ïù¥Î°†ÏùÑ Î∂ÑÏÑùÌïòÍ≥†, Í∞ÄÏû• Ï†ÅÌï©Ìïú ÏÉâÏÉÅ Ï°∞Ìï©ÏùÑ Ï†úÏïàÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

 

ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, "Îî∞ÎúªÌïú Í∞ÄÏùÑ"Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÎ•º ÏûÖÎ†•ÌïòÎ©¥ (ÌïúÍ∏Ä Í∞ÄÎä•)  AIÎäî Ï£ºÌô©ÏÉâ, Í∞àÏÉâ, Î∂âÏùÄ Í≥ÑÏó¥Í≥º Í∞ôÏùÄ Îî∞ÎúªÌïú ÏÉâÏÉÅÏùÑ Ï§ëÏã¨ÏúºÎ°ú ÌåîÎ†àÌä∏Î•º Íµ¨ÏÑ±Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÏÉâÏÉÅ Ï°∞Ìï©ÏùÄ ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§Îü¨Ïö¥ Ï°∞ÌôîÎ•º Ïù¥Î£®Î©∞, Î∏åÎûúÎìú ÏïÑÏù¥Îç¥Ìã∞Ìã∞ Í∞ïÌôîÏôÄ ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖ Ìö®Í≥º Ï¶ùÎåÄÏóê Í∏∞Ïó¨Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

Ï£ºÏöî ÌäπÏßï:

  • ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê ÏπúÌôîÏ†ÅÏù∏ Í≤∞Í≥º Ï†úÍ≥µ

posts.content:
The "sixth" field (the rest of the line) specifies the command to be run. The entire command portion of the line, up to a newline or % character, will be executed by /bin/sh or by the shell specified in the SHELL variable of the cronfile. Percent-signs (%) in the command, unless escaped with backslash (\), will be changed into newline characters, and all data after the first % will be sent to the command as standard input.

ref. crontab(5)

ÌÅ¨Î°†ÌÉ≠(crontab) Îì±Î°ùÌï† Îïå Î™ÖÎ†πÏñ¥Ïóê ÏûàÎäî ÌçºÏÑºÌä∏(%) Í∏∞Ìò∏Îäî Í∞úÌñâÏúºÎ°ú Î≥ÄÍ≤ΩÎêòÍ≥† Ïù¥ÌõÑ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÄ Ïä§ÌÉ†Îã§Îìú Ïù∏ÌíãÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ÑÎã¨ÎêòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÌçºÏÑºÌä∏ Í∏∞Ìò∏Î•º Î∞±Ïä¨ÎûòÏãú(\)Î°ú Ïù¥Ïä§ÏºÄÏù¥ÌîÑ Ìï¥Ï§òÏïº ÌïúÎã§.

Percent-signs (%) in the command, unless escaped with backslash (\), will be changed into newline characters, and all data after the first % will be sent to the command as standard input.


ref. crontab(5)

ÎåÄÌïúÌï≠Í≥µÏùÑ ÏûêÏ£º ÌÉÄÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ÎùºÎ©¥, Ï¢åÏÑùÎßàÎã§ Î∞∞ÏπòÎêú Í∏∞ÎÇ¥ÏßÄ Morning CalmÏùÑ Î≥¥Í±∞ÎÇò, ÏùΩÏñ¥Î¥§ÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïù¥ Ïû°ÏßÄÏùò Ïù¥Î¶ÑÏùò Ïú†ÎûòÎäî ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÑ ÏòÅÏñ¥Î°ú Land of Morning CalmÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌï¥ÏÑúÏù∏Îç∞, Ïù¥ ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏùÄ ‚ÄòÏ°∞ÏÑ†‚ÄôÏùÑ ÏòÅÏñ¥Î°ú ÌíÄÏñ¥ Ìï¥ÏÑùÌïú Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏóêÎã§Í∞Ä Ï°∞Í∏à Îçî Ìï¥ÏÑùÏùÑ Î∂ôÏó¨Î≥¥ÏûêÎ©¥, ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÄ Í≤ΩÏπòÍ∞Ä Ï¢ãÍ≥†, ÏïÑÎ¶ÑÎã§Ïö¥ ÏÇ∞Í≥º Í∞ïÏù¥ ÎßéÏïÑÏÑú, ÏïÑÏπ®Ïóê Î≥¥Î©¥ Ïù¥ ÌíçÍ≤ΩÏù¥ ÏïÑÏ£º Í≥†ÏöîÌïòÍ≥† ÌèâÌôîÎ°úÏõåÏÑú Morning CalmÏù¥ÎùºÎäî ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏù¥ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏôÄ Ïûò Ïñ¥Ïö∏Î¶∞Îã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. ÏßÄÍ∏àÍπåÏßÄÎäî.
ÎÇòÎäî Ïù¥Ï†ú Ïù¥ Morning CalmÏùÄ ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÑ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ï¢ãÏùÄ Î™ÖÏÇ¨Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. Ï°∞Ïö©ÌïòÎã§Í≥† ÌïòÍ∏∞Ïóê ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÄ Ïù¥Ï†ú ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ïó≠ÎèôÏ†ÅÏù¥Í≥† Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú ÎÇòÎùºÍ∞Ä ÎêòÏñ¥Í∞ÄÍ≥† ÏûàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. ÏµúÍ∑º 2ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî ÏÉÅÎãπÌûà ÎßéÏùÄ Ïô∏Íµ≠ Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎ•º ÌïúÍµ≠ÏóêÏÑú ÎßåÎÇ¨Í≥†, ÎØ∏Íµ≠, ÎèôÎÇ®ÏïÑ, ÏùºÎ≥∏, Ïú†ÎüΩ Îì±Ïùò ÎÇòÎùºÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ ÏàòÎßéÏùÄ Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Í≥º Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÎäîÎç∞, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ï†ÑÏóê Ìè¨Ïä§ÌåÖÌñàÎìØÏù¥ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî ÎÇòÎùºÏùò Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÏôÄ ÏúÑÏÉÅÏù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ï¢ãÏïÑÏ°åÎã§Îäî Í±∏ Îß§Î≤à ÎäêÎÇÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÎã§.
Ïù¥Îì§Í≥º Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥, ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ Í∞ñÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÎäî Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ∞ÅÏÉâÏù¥ÏßÄÎßå, ÎåÄÌôî Ï§ëÏóê Ìï≠ÏÉÅ ÌïúÎëê Î≤à ÌäÄÏñ¥ÎÇòÏò§Îäî Îã®Ïñ¥Í∞Ä ÏûàÏóàÎäîÎç∞, Í∑∏ Îã®Ïñ¥Í∞Ä Î∞îÎ°ú ‚Äúintense‚ÄùÏôÄ ‚Äúintensity‚ÄùÏòÄÎã§. Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ Î≥∏ ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÄ ÏïÑÏ£º Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú ÎÇòÎùºÏù∏ Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.
ÏùºÎã® ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Í¥ÄÎ¨∏Ïù∏ Í≥µÌï≠Ïóê ÎÇ¥Î†§ÏÑú ÏàôÏÜåÎ°ú Ïò§Îäî Í∏∏ÏóêÏÑú Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÎäî ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò ÍµêÌÜµÏ≤¥Ï¶ùÏùÄ Ï†ïÎßê Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÎã§. Í∑∏ ÍµêÌÜµÏ≤¥Ï¶ùÏùò ÌïúÍ∞ÄÏö¥Îç∞ÏóêÏÑú Í∏∏Ïóê ÏûàÎäî Îã§Î•∏ Ï∞®Î•º Î≥¥ÎäîÎç∞, Ï¢ãÏùÄ Ï∞®Îì§ ÎòêÌïú ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎßéÎã§. Îã®ÏúÑ Î©¥Ï†Å Îãπ ÎπÑÏãº Ï∞®Îì§Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÎßéÏùÄ ÎÇòÎùº Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùº Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨ Ïô∏Íµ≠ Ìà¨ÏûêÏûê Ìïú Î∂ÑÏù¥ ÏÑúÏö∏Ïóê ÏÇºÏùº ÏûàÏóàÎäîÎç∞, ÌèâÏÉù 70ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà Ï†Ñ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑú Î¥§Îçò Î≤§Ï∏† ÎßàÏù¥Î∞îÌùê Ïà´ÏûêÎ≥¥Îã§ Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ ÎßàÏù¥Î∞îÌùêÎ•º ÏÇ¨Ìùò ÎèôÏïà ÏÑúÏö∏ÏóêÏÑú Î¥§Îã§Î©¥ÏÑú Ï†ïÎßê Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú(=Î≠îÍ∞Ä ÎØ∏Ïπú) ÎèÑÏãúÎùºÍ≥† ÌñàÎçò Í∏∞ÏñµÏù¥ ÎÇúÎã§.
ÌïúÍµ≠ ÏùåÏãùÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïù∏ÏÉÅÎèÑ ÎπÑÏä∑ÌïòÎã§. ÍπÄÏπòÎÇò Ï∞åÍ∞úÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ ÏùåÏãùÏùÄ ÏñëÎÖêÏù¥ ÏÑ∏Í≥† ÏûêÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏù¥ÎùºÏÑú Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÍ≥†, Í∞àÎπÑÎÇò Î∂àÍ≥†Í∏∞ Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≥†Í∏∞Î•òÎäî Îßõ ÏûàÏñ¥ÏÑú Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÎã§. ÌäπÌûà Íπ®Ïïå Í∞ôÏùÄ Î∞òÏ∞¨Ïóê Í∞êÌÉÑÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ ÏóÜÎã§. ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Í≥º Ïà†ÏùÑ Ìïú Î≤àÏù¥ÎùºÎèÑ Î®πÏñ¥Î≥∏ Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Îì§ÏùÄ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Ïà† Î¨∏ÌôîÎ•º ÏôÑÏ†Ñ Ï¶ùÏò§ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò, ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÏÇ¨ÎûëÌïòÍ≤å ÎêúÎã§. Îã§ÏñëÌïú Ïà†Í≥º Ïù¥ Ïà†ÏùÑ Î®πÎäî Îã§ÏñëÌïú Î∞©Î≤ï, Ïó¨Í∏∞Ïóê Îß§Ïö∞ Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú Ïù∏ÏÉÅÏùÄ Î∞õÏùÄ Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÏÉÅÎãπÌûà ÎßéÎã§.
ÏºÄÏù¥ÌåùÍ≥º ÏºÄÏù¥ÎìúÎùºÎßàÎ•º ÏûêÏ£º Ï†ëÌïòÎäî Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Îì§ÎèÑ Îã§ÏñëÌïú ÏùòÍ≤¨ÏùÑ Ïö∞Î¶¨ÏôÄ Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Ìïú Îã®Ïñ¥Î°ú Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò ÎäêÎÇåÏùÑ ÏöîÏïΩÌïòÎ©¥, ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Í∞Ä Îß§Ïö∞ Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÎã§Í≥† Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§. ÌäπÌûà, Ïò§ÏßïÏñ¥Í≤åÏûÑÍ≥º Í∏∞ÏÉùÏ∂©ÏùÑ Î¥§Îçò ÌèâÎ°†Í∞ÄÎì§Ïùò ÌèâÏùÑ Î≥¥Î©¥, Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÎã§Îäî ÌëúÌòÑÏùÑ ÏûêÏ£º ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî Í±∏ Î≥º Ïàò ÏûàÎã§.
ÌïúÍµ≠ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Í≥º ÏùºÏùÑ Ìï¥ Î≥∏ Ïô∏Íµ≠Ïù∏Îì§ÎèÑ Ïù¥ ‚Äúintense‚ÄùÎùºÎäî ÎßêÏùÑ ÏûêÏ£º ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Ï£ºÎ°ú Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏùòÎØ∏Î°ú ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÎêúÎã§Í≥† ÎÇòÎäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. ÏùºÎã® Ï†ÑÎ∞òÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§ÏùÄ Ï†ïÎßê ÏùºÏùÑ ÏûòÌïòÍ≥†, ÏùºÎ®∏Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏûàÍ≥†, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† (ÏïÑÏßÅÍπåÏßÑ) ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ Ï†ïÎßê Ïó¥Ïã¨Ìûà ÏùºÌïúÎã§Îäî ÌîºÎìúÎ∞±Ïù¥ ÏßÄÎ∞∞Ï†ÅÏù¥Îã§. ÏùºÏùÑ ÏûòÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÏùºÏùÑ Ïó¥Ïã¨Ìûà ÍπåÏßÄ ÌïòÎ©¥, Ïù¥Í±¥ ÍµâÏû•Ìûà Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÍ≤å ÏùºÏùÑ ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. ÏûëÎÖÑÏóê Ïú†ÎüΩÏóêÏÑú Í∞ÄÎäî Í≥≥ÎßàÎã§ ÌïúÍµ≠ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Îä¶Í≤åÍπåÏßÄ ÏùºÌï¥ÏÑú, Î≥∏Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÌéòÏù¥Ïä§ ÎßûÏ∂∞ÏÑú Í∞ôÏù¥ ÏùºÌïòÎäî Í≤å ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÌûòÎì§Îã§Îäî Î∂àÌèâ ÏïÑÎãå Î∂àÌèâÏùÑ ÏûêÏ£º Îì§ÏóàÎäîÎç∞, Ïó≠Ïãú Ïù¥Î∂ÑÎì§ÎèÑ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§ÏùÄ Ï†ïÎßê Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌïòÍ≤å ÏùºÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÌñàÎã§. Î≠ê, ÏõåÎÇô Í≤åÏúºÎ•∏ Ïú†ÎüΩ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ÎùºÏÑú ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Ïó¥Ïã¨Ìûà ÏùºÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÌñàÏùÑ ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§.
Ï∂îÏö¥ Í≤®Ïö∏ÏóêÎèÑ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎßéÏùÄ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÏïÑÏù¥Ïä§ ÏïÑÎ©îÎ¶¨Ïπ¥ÎÖ∏Î•º ÏãúÏºúÏÑú Ï∂•Îã§Î©¥ÏÑú Í∑∏ Ï∞®Í∞ÄÏö¥ Ïª§ÌîºÎ•º Î≤åÏª•Î≤åÏª• Î®πÎäî Í≤å Îß§Ïö∞ Ïù∏ÏÉÅÏ†ÅÏù¥ÏóàÎã§Îäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÏµúÍ∑ºÏóê Îì§ÏóàÎã§. ÏïÑÏ£º Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú Ïù∏ÏÉÅÏùÑ ÎÇ®Í≤ºÎã§Îäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏÑ±ÌòïÏàòÏà†ÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥† ÌâÅÌâÅ Î∂ÄÏùÄ ÏñºÍµ¥Ïóê Î∂ïÎåÄÎ•º Ïπ≠Ïπ≠ Í∞êÍ≥† ÏãúÎÇ¥Î•º ÏïÑÎ¨¥Î†áÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÍ≤å ÎèåÏïÑÎã§ÎãàÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ÎèÑ Îß§Ïö∞ Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌñàÍ≥†, Í∑∏Îü∞ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùÑ Î≥¥Í≥†ÎèÑ ÏïÑÎ¨¥Î†áÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÏùÄ ÎìØÏù¥ Í±∏Ïñ¥ Îã§ÎãàÎäî ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïù∏ÏÉÅÎèÑ Ï∞∏ÏúºÎ°ú Í∞ïÎ†¨ÌñàÎã§Îäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÎèÑ Îì§ÏóàÎã§. Ïñ¥Ï®åÎì† Ïù¥Îü∞ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìï®Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏóêÌîºÏÜåÎìúÎäî ÎÅäÏûÑÏóÜÏù¥ ÎßéÎã§.
Ïôú ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Î™®Îì† Í≤å Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìï†Íπå? ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å Í∞úÏù∏Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î¨ºÏñ¥Î≥∏Îã§Î©¥, Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Í±∏ ÎßåÎì§Í≥†, Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Í±∏ Í∞ÄÎä•ÏºÄ ÌïòÎäî ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§ ÏûêÏ≤¥Í∞Ä Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú ÎØºÏ°±Ïù¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. Ïö∞Î¶∞ Î≠ò ÌïòÎÇò ÌïòÎ©¥, Ï†ïÎßê ÎÅùÏùÑ Î≥¥Îäî ÏÑ±Í≤©ÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÑ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥Í≥†, Ìïú Î≤à ÌïòÎ†§Í≥† ÎßàÏùåÎ®πÏùÄ Í±¥ Ï†ïÎßê Ïûò ÌïúÎã§.(ÏãúÏûëÌïòÍ≥† ÎÅùÏùÑ Î™ª Î≥¥Îäî Í≤ÉÎì§ÎèÑ ÎßéÍ∏¥ ÌïòÏßÄÎßå).
ÎÇòÎäî Ïù¥Îü∞ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìï®ÏùÄ Í≥ÑÏÜç Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Ïú†ÏßÄÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥Ïñ¥ ÎÇòÍ∞ÄÏïº ÌïòÎäî Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏäµÍ¥ÄÏù¥Ïûê ÌäπÏßïÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. Ïù¥Í±∏ ÎÇòÏÅòÍ≤å Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌïòÎ©¥, Ïö∞Î¶∞ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ Î∞îÏÅòÍ≤å ÏÇ¥Í≥† ÏûàÍ≥†, ÏïûÎí§ Í∞ÄÎ¶¨ÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÎÉÑÎπÑÍ∑ºÏÑ±Ïù¥Í≥†, Ïä§Ïä§Î°ú ÏûêÏ†úÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎäî ÎØºÏ°±Ïù¥ÎùºÍ≥† Ìï† ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÏßÄÎßå, ÎÇòÎäî Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ Ïù¥Îü∞ DNAÎ•º Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Í≥ÑÏÜç Ïûò Îã§Îì¨Í≥†, Ï¢ãÏùÄ Ï™ΩÏúºÎ°ú Í≥ÑÏÜç Î∞úÏ†ÑÏãúÏºúÏïº ÌïúÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§.
